title_review: Hidden pearl close to touristic routes

The atmosphere is both Spanish and modern, business customers mix with families and tourists who find a bypass to the Gran Via.  Service was caring professionell with a twist of Spanish charme, the (red and white) wine by the glass moderate priced and well chosen. For food we took the fresh cut Jambon, Cheeseplate and other easy to eat dishes available at the bar, what was of excellent quality and presentation.  Definitely a recommendation for all city center visitors who search for a stylish, individual and relaxed Spanish setting before kicking the night off.

review_preview: Wanted to try a restaurant away from the tourist haunts.  Chose this restaurant as it was close to our hotel on Retiro and had good reviews.So pleased that we found this place. Visited on Sunday evening and had booked in advance-  the restaurant is...
review_full: Wanted to try a restaurant away from the tourist haunts. Chose this restaurant as it was close to our hotel on Retiro and had good reviews. So pleased that we found this place. Visited on Sunday evening and had booked in advance- the restaurant is just perfect - fairly small, very friendly , loads of atmosphere & buzzing with locals of all ages. We were the only tourists in there and we were really well looked after by Louis & his team.  There is a good choice of food and we were advised about how much to order. The recommendations were all delicious and we were very full when we left. Particularly enjoyed the croquettes and scrambled egg dish. Some nice touches like complementary appetiser at the start and little 'cocktail desert ' at the end. When we return to Madrid will definitely be visiting again. Thank you so much for making us so welcome.

review_preview: Absolutely fantastic place. They don't speak much English but it didn't matter. They are so friendly and really care about making your visit enjoyable. The food is fantastic.  We went twice as the first quick lunch made us want to spend longer. The food highlights...
review_full: Absolutely fantastic place. They don't speak much English but it didn't matter. They are so friendly and really care about making your visit enjoyable. The food is fantastic. We went twice as the first quick lunch made us want to spend longer. The food highlights of the visits were many. The scrambled egg wasn't what we expected but was delicious. I loved the mushrooms, baby broad beans with spinach crisps, I didn't want to share! Both the baked noodles and rice were lovely but big portions, enough to share. Possibly our favourite was the fried pork belly, served pink, it was incredible. So tender and a fabulous flavour. Wine was excellent. The price for such a fantastic quality meal was amazing. Our first time in Madrid but we've really enjoyed it. We'll be back and we'll be sure to visit here again too

review_preview: This small bar/restaurant (there is not a separate restaurant area) is situated very near to Retiro Park in a quiet residential area of the city. However, it is well worth finding. During a lengthy stay in Madrid we ate there several times and thoroughly enjoyed...
review_full: This small bar/restaurant (there is not a separate restaurant area) is situated very near to Retiro Park in a quiet residential area of the city. However, it is well worth finding. During a lengthy stay in Madrid we ate there several times and thoroughly enjoyed every occasion. There is an excellent and varied menu, including some first class rice dishes. title_review: Dining at Esplore: The Good, The Bad, & The Bizarre
review_preview: Let’s start with the good. I made the dinner reservation in a hurry and didn’t realize that it was for a degustation menu. However, I can say that I was happy that I inadvertently did. For this menu, you get two starters (zucchini salad and...
review_full: Let’s start with the good. I made the dinner reservation in a hurry and didn’t realize that it was for a degustation menu. However, I can say that I was happy that I inadvertently did. For this menu, you get two starters (zucchini salad and smoked salmon), two main dishes (ravioli and Iberian pork), two desserts (dark chocolate cake and torrija), paired with a wine or liqueur for each course. I have to say that the food was well prepared and portioned, and the wines of good quality. Definitely a good dining experience and well worth the EUR25 price. I will be recommending this place to my Madrileno friends to try out. Now, the bad. Compared to other smallish degustation menus that I have tried before, this menu is a set, and I mean a SET so there are no other options to choose from. If you have any dietary constraints (e.g., pork, nuts, alcohol), this menu may not be for you. And finally, the bizarre. Just before the dessert, I inquired about the ravioli, and was told it was the third dish I was served. I had to rack my brain to remember what the third dish was, and what I remembered was slices of meat on a bed of vegetable puree. However, the manager insisted that I was served ravioli so I asked to see what their ravioli looked like (just in case ravioli means something else in Spain). From what I was shown, I can categorically say that the third dish was not ravioli. I don’t eat a lot of pasta, but I would like to think I know a ravioli when I see one. Bizarre indeed!

title_review: Beautifully served and wonderful to eat! Great owner - very welcoming!
review_preview: This is one of the best restaurants I have ever been to - let alone in Madrid. Every dish of the 6 we tasted was beautifully presented and absolutely delicious. The octopus was tender and melted in our mouth, the rabbit fell of the bone,...
review_full: This is one of the best restaurants I have ever been to - let alone in Madrid. Every dish of the 6 we tasted was beautifully presented and absolutely delicious. The octopus was tender and melted in our mouth, the rabbit fell of the bone, the mussels spicy and original, the foie crunchy on the outside and soft in the middle, the goat's cheese mellow and creamy and mojito sorbet - wow! If you're not in the mood for food (but you will be once you step inside and hear all the delighted moans of joy!) just step in to have a drink and a chat with the owner who is friendly and welcoming with a pride for serving great food :) What a great place - I am so, so happy we chanced across it. Don't be put off by the simple, canteen-esque decor, the food is without a doubt 10/10.

review_preview: You wouldn't know it from the outside, but this place offers up some excellent food.Our server was welcoming, and spoke excellent English. He even humored us as we tried to order some in Spanish.The food is served in stages, which the three of...
review_full: You wouldn't know it from the outside, but this place offers up some excellent food. Our server was welcoming, and spoke excellent English. He even humored us as we tried to order some in Spanish. The food is served in stages, which the three of us shared. We started with guacamole and banana chips, followed by goat's cheese with basil and honey. We then moved on to seafood, with mussels in a tikka masala sauce and octopus. We ended with pork on skewers. Each dish was better than the last, and I think you'd be hard-pressed to find a bad thing on this menu. The meals weren't, strictly speaking, traditional Spanish dishes, but rather unique takes on classics. We ended with three different, delicious desserts: cheesecake, blackberries and white chocolate cream, and strawberries with vanilla sorbet and coca cola extract. They were all great. Some other thoughts: the food is delicious, but the portions aren't huge (especially if you're coming from the States). The desserts were fantastic, but a bit pricy (6 euros a piece). In hind sight, they were actually quite large, and we probably could have shared two.  Overall, our meal came to 68 euros, with all the above mentioned dishes, lots of bread (you'll want to use it to enjoy all your extra sauce), and a beer. Considering the quality of the food and service, we all felt this place was an excellent value.

review_preview: We enjoyed 2 dinners here - one excellent and one good. Firstly, we are vegetarians and were happy to find some vegetarian options. Their salad is one of my favorite in Madrid - ask for the balsamic dressing on the side if you like to...
review_full: We enjoyed 2 dinners here - one excellent and one good. Firstly, we are vegetarians and were happy to find some vegetarian options. Their salad is one of my favorite in Madrid - ask for the balsamic dressing on the side if you like to control how much dressing is on your salad. Their chocolate dessert with dulce de leche or chocolate ice cream is excellent. We loved the salted potatoes with red sauce but were not fans of their patatas brava. Croquettes were great too and we wished we had ordered those again the second time rather than the goat cheese with mango chutney. Definitely make a reservation if you want a table as this restaurant is very popular with the locals. They are very responsive on email. Closed Mondays.

review_full: This restaurant is of the quality, both in terms of food and joyful experience, that makes it a destination by itself for true foodies. We usually stay at the the Westin Palace and take a leisurely walk through the beautiful El Parque del Buen Retiro to and from the restaurant. We now schedule our visits to make sure we have time to enjoy a meal at Vinos both when arriving in Spain and as our last memory when we are leaving. If I lived in Madrid, this is the place that I would want to meet friends to drink a bottle of wine, to have a quick bite in the bar, or to have a wonderful meal. The staff are so friendly and cool that you want to become friends with them as well! Every dish is to die for, but I especially crave the bellota pork dish. Vinos, as the name suggests, also has a very nice, modestly priced wine list. Just writing this makes me want to plan another trip to Madrid!

The menu had a English translation but Moad went through it with us just in case there was anything we didn't understand. The rest of the staff were equally friendly and attentive.The food was wonderful and served quickly and efficiently. The kitchen is open so you an see your food been cooked by very calm efficient chefs. This restaurant is certainlyworth a visit if you are nearby. It is extremely well run by Moad and his team. title_review: Go, you will be glad you did
review_preview: We went here based on Trip Advisor reviews and we were glad we did.  It is a bar, but it is a neighborhood place were everybody knows everybody, but outsiders are welcome.  The service was personable and helpful, although no one spoke English, everyone was...
review_full: We went here based on Trip Advisor reviews and we were glad we did. It is a bar, but it is a neighborhood place were everybody knows everybody, but outsiders are welcome. The service was personable and helpful, although no one spoke English, everyone was accommodating. The cheese croquetas and the cured beef and mushroom croquetas were the best in Spain the red pepper salad was good with tuna, but the rice with mushrooms and duck was great. The desserts were reasonable and very good. Wine by the glass was well priced and a great selection. Go. It has a big screen TV with futbol on. Unfortunately everyone was cheering against my favorite team that night (Barca) and it wasn;t even a Madrid team playing them :)

review_preview: This is a tiny bar on the east side of Retiro Park.  Tapas and entrees served. THE best croquettas we had in Spain, crunchy on the outside, creamy on the inside, one type filled with a mushroom cream, the other with manchego. Also had a...
review_full: This is a tiny bar on the east side of Retiro Park. Tapas and entrees served. THE best croquettas we had in Spain, crunchy on the outside, creamy on the inside, one type filled with a mushroom cream, the other with manchego. Also had a fried mussel tapa. These were bizarre but I liked them very much. Mussel shell filled with a mussel cream, then breaded and deep fried. We also had the black pudding that was wrapped in a crispy pastry shell, looked like the size of a pirouette cookie. Also had a rice dish with duck confit. It was really good, much better than Valencia paella. They had another rice dish with mushrooms and beans, but didn't see that one until after we ordered. The only dish that I would rate "good" but not great, was a tuna and roasted red peppers. The waiter thought I had ordered it, but we didn't == just a miscommunication in languages. He was so nice and we didn't want to offend him, so accepted it. I was expecting raw tuna, but it was cooked, which I am really not a fan of, however, the flavors paired really well. All dishes were plated creatively. I think reservations are essential. Very casual place, with a big screen TV that had soccer game playing which made the place more fun. Just two guys running the place, a bartender and the waiter. The bar tender was mixing what looked like killer drinks. Wine by the bottle and glass (nice pours and only 2.10E each!). Definitely a local hangout.

It's hard to spend over 20 Euros at a restaurant. 5 Euros in the store gets a great bottle. (that's just a side note) The seared goat cheese with pesto.Really, how can that be so good but it was awesome. Fried eggs over fry's, yup, some how elevated. The mussels were great and the ribs were off the charts. The only item that was a miss was the octopus. the foam it came in looked great but to me it's only proof that foam can some times actually not be cool but weird but not in a good way. I still give them 5 stars however.

review_preview: I stopped in for tapas tonight with my sister and my two young daughters.  We had been vainly looking for another restaurant recommended by a friend but we gave up and opted for this as we liked the look of it. So incredibly pleased we...
review_full: I stopped in for tapas tonight with my sister and my two young daughters. We had been vainly looking for another restaurant recommended by a friend but we gave up and opted for this as we liked the look of it.  So incredibly pleased we did! This place is a find.  We started off with complimentary black pudding parcels and egg salad crisps - they were delicious and an indication of the amazing food standard that was to come. We had beef and cheese croquettes, a beautifully dressed and plentiful salad, goats cheese, wrinkled potatoes. All the dishes were thoughtfully presented and excellently executed.  The desserts didn't disappoint either. We shared home made chocolate and caramel ice cream and a stand-out strawberry cheesecake. It's rare for cheesecake to leave a lasting impression, but this did! Every element of it was 100% on point. From the base to the creamyness/cheesiness factor and the fruit topping....even the sweetness. It really was impressive! The service. Again. Amazing. The waiter - I think he was the owner, helped us order and then we he could see we had perhaps over ordered cancelled our final dish without charge. He checked, unobtrusively, throughout our meal that everything was satisfactory and was just totally charming. I actually cannot wait to recommend this place to my friends. I can't wait to return. This is my go-to Madrid restaurant for every future visit.

We came in at 8pm and the waiter told us that we can be seated until 10pm as there was another reservation coming (which was totally fine for us), but then he started coming to our table to ask if we are finished starting from 9pm. The waiter helped us to choose the wine and proposed a bottle. We liked the wine a lot (thank you!) and asked for the second one, but there was no one left (seriously? in the beginning of the Friday evening?), and the second one recommended was not so good at all. That is why the service was also not the thing we were fond of. So many places much worth to visit in Chueca area.

review_preview: We were staying in a hotel near this restaurant to it flagged up when we searched tripadvisor for the nearest ones. It's in a small side street so glad we looked it up as we wouldn't have just stumbled upon it!We arrived just after...
review_full: We were staying in a hotel near this restaurant to it flagged up when we searched tripadvisor for the nearest ones. It's in a small side street so glad we looked it up as we wouldn't have just stumbled upon it! We arrived just after 8.30, we hadn't reserved but they had a table for 2. If you intend to arrive later than this probably best to book as the restaurant filled up quickly, mostly with bookings. Waiters were really friendly, I am a Spanish speaker but my friend isn't so when they realised I was translating for her they were more than happy to explain everything in excellent English. They advised us to share a couple of the smaller dishes to start and then have a main, either from the meat section or the rice section. We shared the goats cheese in honey and basil and the octopus with foamed potatoes. Both were absolutely fantastic and good sized portions. Definitely could have eaten them twice over! We then shared Fideua as a main which is like paella but instead of rice uses small noodles. This was also fantastic, a more than ample portion for two people and although we were both quite full we couldn't bring ourselves to leave any! We didn't have dessert, too full up, but we saw some people having the famed mojito sorbet and they said how good it was. We also had a couple of glasses of nice wine with our meal. Had we been staying longer in Madrid I'm certain we would have returned here to try some of the other things on the menu and I'd definitely return next time I'm in Madrid. Food was fantastic, Spanish but with a modern twist and very reasonably priced for the quality.

review_preview: After reading reviews on Trip Advisor, we decided to try this restaurant for our last evening in Madrid. We wanted to try authentic Spanish food, where locals may choose to eat. This is a small restaurant but when we arrived at 7.30 there were only...
review_full: After reading reviews on Trip Advisor, we decided to try this restaurant for our last evening in Madrid. We wanted to try authentic Spanish food, where locals may choose to eat. This is a small restaurant but when we arrived at 7.30 there were only two other tables occupied, the decor is simple but lovely. The waiters are attentive and try very hard to communicate in English, which was good as we know no Spanish. On arrival we were treated to an amuse bouche which was delightful and at the end of the meal we were given a dish of sweets - lovely! Where they thought we were over ordering they suggested we hold back which proved sensible, they advised on the menu successfully and we enjoyed all of our food. The small portion of patas bravas was enough for two as a started and completely delicious. My son had the salad filled with nuts and a lovely dressing, For main I had the hake, my partner had the monkfish with noodles and my son the croquettes. He also managed cheesecake which he assured us was fabulous. We rounded the meal off with Irish coffee which was perfect. The bill was reasonable barely €50 for the food for three, all left very full. Definitely worth the 30 minute walk through the park.

title_review: really great place. very highly recommended
review_preview: went there for dinner based on tripadvisor recommendations and the reviews are absolutely on target. it's in a non-descript part of madrid and the decor of the place is average in every way. the averageness ends there. the food was incredibly good. they bring you...
review_full: went there for dinner based on tripadvisor recommendations and the reviews are absolutely on target. it's in a non-descript part of madrid and the decor of the place is average in every way. the averageness ends there.  the food was incredibly good. they bring you an amuse bouche to start which is a nice surprise, and it was excellent. i then ordered some pork thing as my main dish and they brought it out surprisingly quickly. it was so good it almost melted in your mouth. the wine was excellent and cost nothing (between 2€ and 4€ per glass). for dessert i ordered the cheesecake and i could tell the waiter was slightly disappointed because apparently they're more proud of their tiramisu. but the cheesecake was honestly some of the best i've ever had. i thought the meal was finished but it was not. they then brought me some sort of small dessert café thing. it wasn't coffee but like a cream thing in a small glass. delectable. i thought i was done. i was not. then they brought a little candy dish with gumdrops in it. gumdrops??!! who in 2016 brings gumdrops to your table? i loved it.  the whole experience - including 2 glasses of wine - cost 26€. i don't know how that's even possible. very, very highly recommended

review_preview: This restaurant is a gem. The best tapas of my life. Truely unique combinations of flavours and using only the very best ingredients. The chef has worked at the famous El Bulli together with Rene Redzepi, the chef of Noma in Denmark, voted as the...
review_full: This restaurant is a gem. The best tapas of my life. Truely unique combinations of flavours and using only the very best ingredients. The chef has worked at the famous El Bulli together with Rene Redzepi, the chef of Noma in Denmark, voted as the world's best restaurant. Well Gastromaquia has the same philosophy of using top local produce and combining them in ways you have never tried before. They do more than tapas. The dark chocolate desert was also fantastic - explosion of flavours. Service was also excellent and the chef took a lot of time to guide us in ordering and chatting with us. Among the best dinning experiences in my life - and I have been to Noma. This place is just much more affordable. When in Madrid, go there. Amazing experience.

Staff is attentive and chat a lot with the customers, but at the end I know Spain for years and this is not the best Tapas example. Maybe it's OK if you haven't tried many tapas in your life, but Spain has much better to offer and I am sure in Madrid there should be plenty other more. I've tried tapas in other smaller towns in Spain and they were much much better. Unfortunately I would not recommeend this restaurant, though I understand for tourists it may work as everything is new for them anyway!

review_preview: My wife & I. ate at Gastromaquia this evening....we have booked a return engagement in 3 days. If you are in Madrid, this place must be at the head of your list. It is small, so be sure to book in advance.  The menu in...
review_full: My wife & I. ate at Gastromaquia this evening....we have booked a return engagement in 3 days. If you are in Madrid, this place must be at the head of your list. It is small, so be sure to book in advance. The menu in Spanish will be...not translated, but explained and illuminated by Hugo, the co-owner. Then you will be treated to an array of choices...almost all with a slight creative twist, but all extraordinary and delicious. Every serving but 1 or 2 is large enough for sharing, which Hugo encourages. We shared a salad of goat cheese & greens with a marvelous dressing, my wife had Hugo's version of spare ribs....the meat literally coming off the bone after very slow cooking. I have never tasted spare ribs even remotely as succulent (11.50E).  This is one of the best restaurants I have ever eaten at and surely the best in Madrid so far.

The mussels tikka masala were wonderful and the Iberian pork melted in our mouths. The only thing that kept it from being 5 stars was the neighborhood and the Formica table atmosphere. For foodies, a great find- any great restaurant would be proud to serve it! Enjoy, enjoy.

Hugo & his food are king here, don't expect fancy but do know you will have a great dining experience!

review_preview: We were looking for somewhere doing poached eggs and was struggling to find somewhere, we looked on tripadvisor and came across this place not far from our hotel. The reviews were good so thought we would try turning up without a reservation and luckily there...
review_full: We were looking for somewhere doing poached eggs and was struggling to find somewhere, we looked on tripadvisor and came across this place not far from our hotel. The reviews were good so thought we would try turning up without a reservation and luckily there was a table free. The inside has cute and quirky decor, the staff were friendly and the food was amazing! We opted for the ‘full brunch’ which included either an orange juice, mimosa or cava, a tea or coffee, yoghurt with fruit and granola, selection of breads and croissants with jam etc then followed by a chose of various cooked elements - we opted for the brunch salad which had poached eggs, spinach, avocado and bacon. We were so full after all of that which cost €17 which we felt was a great price for such an amount of food including drinks. There was a smaller option which cost quite a bit less and then a menu which you can choose your own items from. So pleased we found this place thanks to tripadvisor! Shame we found it on our last day in Madrid else we would have definitely visited again.

review_preview: Gastromaquia is in the gay neighborhood of Madrid. This restaurant is small, but service and food is excellent. We got the fried goat cheese with honey and basil oil, octopus with foamed potatoes, and the black rice paella. The goat cheese is served with bread...
review_full: Gastromaquia is in the gay neighborhood of Madrid. This restaurant is small, but service and food is excellent. We got the fried goat cheese with honey and basil oil, octopus with foamed potatoes, and the black rice paella. The goat cheese is served with bread and is so savory. My husband is not a fan of goat cheese, but he LOVED this dish. The honey and the basil oil made the sour taste that is associate with goat cheese disappear. Get this dish when you come here. The foamed potato and octopus was also very good. The octopus was so soft and not hard and rubbery. The dish kind of reminded me of the steamed eggs you get at Japanese restaurants. You can definitely taste the potato in the foam. It was very unique and delicious at the same time. The black rice paella was huge. We were so full after the paella. It takes 25 minute to make but it is worth the wait. It comes out super hot and there is shrimp, mussels, and clams in it. I recommend getting the paella and maybe 2 other dishes or just stick to all there other dishes so you can try more things and not get full from paella. We were STUFFED after our meal and could not finish the paella. The servers here are very attentive and can give you some recommendations if you are a visitor in Madrid. We called the day of to get a reservation for this restaurant because it is small and fills up really fast. There were diners who walked into the restaurant, but could not get a seat because the restaurant was full. The restaurant has great food, great service at an incredible price.

The food was good, the service was pleasant and efficient and the wine was fine. They have menus in English. Our impression was that Vinos de Bellota was run by a few youngish graduates who are destined to make a go of things. Based on the number of, mostly Spanish, people eating and drinking there they are succeeding. We made a reservation for the following night and found Vinos de Bellota even busier with people prepared to wait up to an hour for a table. The food was just as good but the service, although still very pleasant, was much less efficient.  We would strongly recommend Vinos de Bellota and would certainly choose to eat there again. One thing to watch though is that, for some reason, they put payments made by card through in your national currency not Euros. They really should ask first.

The goat cheese with a honey and basil vinaigrette was even the best goat cheese I ever had the pleasure to eat. Five points for this loveable place!

review_preview: Writing this review just after eating at Taberna. The food was very, very well done and the host/waiter/co-owner Hugo was an excellent guide through the menu.  He is a chef as well, speaks great English, and explained his menu nicely.  It is a creative menu...
review_full: Writing this review just after eating at Taberna. The food was very, very well done and the host/waiter/co-owner Hugo was an excellent guide through the menu. He is a chef as well, speaks great English, and explained his menu nicely. It is a creative menu of relatively simple foods but executed well. Goat cheese salad is a must -- my wife is still talking about the dressing. The guacamole is fresh, full of flavor and had me mopping up the last bits with my bread because the plantain chips were gone. My octopus ("pupo") in a "potato foam" was absolutely outstanding. I'm thinking of going back again tomorrow. Asparagus done with parmasean and a light balsamic was simple, flavorful and delightful. The skewers of pork were perfectly spiced, succulent. The restaurant is a small, very casual place that might benefit from a touch more decorating. If you were to walk by and not know what was within you might not stop. But this would be your mistake. The food is great, the prices right, and the host very charming. His passion for the food is very obvious and it shows on the plates. By the way, Hugo worked at Jaleo in Washington, D.C. under Jose Andres which explains a lot about his passion and his execution.

No point going on about the actual menu content as that's all been said and the reviews have been spot on, all I would recommend is that you go and see for yourself and dont forget to book as you might be dissapointed!

title_review: Holy crap this place is good
review_preview: So my girlfriend and I were looking for a last minute place for a dinner reservation and stumbled onto Gastromaquia via Trip Advisor.  Simply put food phenomenal . . . service was great, and the ambiance was relaxed and local.We shared everything we had...
review_full: So my girlfriend and I were looking for a last minute place for a dinner reservation and stumbled onto Gastromaquia via Trip Advisor. Simply put food phenomenal . . . service was great, and the ambiance was relaxed and local. We shared everything we had and probably ordered more than we should as everything sounded so good. We had the potatoes to start with the red pepper sauce which were simple and delicious. Then the goat cheese salad came out which was the best goat cheese I've ever had, warmed to perfection with a slightly crispy bottom layer with an amazing balsamic reduction that was the perfect blend of sweet with the vinegar. Then the Mussels with a tikka masala sauce that was a combination I never would have thought of and was again amazing. The asparagus with the same balsamic reduction and slightly melted finely shredded parmesan cheese was the best by far. Every bite just disintegrated in our mouth's and blew us away. At this point we were both pleasantly stuffed and thought we could handle no more. We had caught notice of one dessert at the table next to us that was intriguing. It was some sort of green gelato with rum poured on top. Our waiter then came up with perfect timing and explained that it was a mojito sorbet. It was just that only better than any mojitio I have ever had. We shared it as it we ate soo much it would have been impossible for us both to have our own. Our waiter recognized us as american and was very curious to hear where we were from and what we were doing in madrid. he made conversation and handled the small but busy resturant well and the food was timely but not rushed. definitely a visit that we will make again.

title_review: Incredible Food, in a no frills environment!
review_preview: I would not have found this place without tripadvisor so I am especially drawn to write a review.  I have now been to Gastromaquia twice and I can happily say that if I had more time in Madrid I know I would be back.  The...
review_full: I would not have found this place without tripadvisor so I am especially drawn to write a review. I have now been to Gastromaquia twice and I can happily say that if I had more time in Madrid I know I would be back. The first time I went with my girlfriend and sisters and I can safely say we ordered nearly half of the menu. The types of dishes they make and the interesting twists they place on Spanish classics displays a true love for food and desire to provide a unique and interesting dinning experience. Add on top of that the helpful staff and fact that one of the two chefs is in charge of the dinning room, so he is always talking about the food and doing so with great English, and you have an incredible dinning experience that is accessible to anyone. Obviously most of the time you would expect to pay excessively for this type of food, but I can happily say that this meal left both our stomachs and wallets 100% satisfied!

title_review: Great food, better service and even better staff!
review_preview: My wife and I came in late the night we before we were going to head out back to the US. The place was pretty much empty and they said they were out of food. Initially he, the host (also server) said that if we...
review_full: My wife and I came in late the night we before we were going to head out back to the US. The place was pretty much empty and they said they were out of food. Initially he, the host (also server) said that if we came back tomorrow, they would be able to do a better job of serving us. We didn't ask but I think he was also the chef. He was very chatty and I think that made the meal that much better. He had spent some time in NYC and spoke pretty English quite well. When told that this was our last night in Madrid, he said his food options were limited, as they had run out of most of their food. We said we would take whatever.  The starters were delicious, potatoes in an amazing local sauce and guacamole, and the local beer and wine were great as well. They were recommended by the host with significant discussion regarding sourcing the wine (which was pretty cheap BTW).  The rabbit was very good and the pork skewers were absolutely delicious. The chocolate dessert was awesome. I think the food was very good, we would have given it 4 stars based on just the food. Then again I would never have ordered guacamole in Spain when I live in California. Thats not to say it wasn't very good and given the slim pickings, the late night accomodation, I wish I could give them 6 stars. Overall for 1 beer, 1 wine and a bottle of water, 2 good sized appetizers and 2 main dishes as well as desert, the total was just under 50 euros. The priceless service and accomodation we will be thankful forever as my pregnant wife was starving.

review_preview: Close to the Retiro park.Very small, busy and noisy restaurant. A few tables to sit down and also "bar/counter area".The welcome and customer care was great. Service was good and the friendly young waiter gave us some useful information about the items on...
review_full: Close to the Retiro park. Very small, busy and noisy restaurant. A few tables to sit down and also "bar/counter area". The welcome and customer care was great. Service was good and the friendly young waiter gave us some useful information about the items on the menu list. We liked the tapas to share like "asadillo de piementa"/pepper salad with tuna, "croquets exoticas"(3 different tastes), "crujiente queso"(crispy baked goat cheese). Nice home made ice cream to finish (chocolate, nougat, tangerine). Large choice of tasty Spanish wine by the glass. Vermuth and beer also available. Rather overcrowded and loud restaurant where you grab some "vinos&tapas", not a place for a quiet, romantic dinner. Good price/quality ratio. Recommend the "Vinos de Bellota" to try delicious and creative tapas and enjoy Spanish wine "copas de vino".

review_preview: We were three friends out for dinner and decided to try this place based on the reviews.  They were spot on.  The food was just great.  We split a delicious salad first.  Then had the baked goat cheese with jam or sautéed onions.  Next came...
review_full: We were three friends out for dinner and decided to try this place based on the reviews. They were spot on. The food was just great. We split a delicious salad first. Then had the baked goat cheese with jam or sautéed onions. Next came sumptuous but light croquettes of alligator, cheese and meat. They were the only non greasy ones I have had. It was followed up with toasted rice with porcini and duck confit. It just blew me away. The flavors in this dish were so perfectly blended together I could have just kept going back for seconds and thirds, etc... I was too full for dessert but the other two had the tiramisu and loved it.  They also gave us wonderful complimentary aperitifs of soup and a whipped coffee confection for dessert.  Service was excellent and prices very reasonable.

review_preview: Following the reviews on TripAdvisor, we managed to get a reservation here for a Sunday dinner. Initially the restaurant was not really what we expected, as the bar is fairly dominant when one enters and it seems that this place is more renown for its...
review_full: Following the reviews on TripAdvisor, we managed to get a reservation here for a Sunday dinner. Initially the restaurant was not really what we expected, as the bar is fairly dominant when one enters and it seems that this place is more renown for its drinks. But once the food is served, you know you are in the right place. We had a variety of starters, all excellently cooked. The foie gras with a gin sauce was the best I have ever tasted. The wine list is short, as is the menu, but the quality is perfect. The restaurant also boasts a long gin list and a very good homemade Gin Fizz shot. Our waiter was extremely friendly and helpful. When the bill came, we were surprised about the low price. An absolutely excellent restaurant and do recommend to reserve a table. Even on Sunday, guests still came past 22:00.

review_preview: If you get the chance to come here - then seize the moment. You must book as it is tiny. There is a relaxed but caring atmosphere - with everything done with an eye for detail. Although I had booked we had to wait for...
review_full: If you get the chance to come here - then seize the moment. You must book as it is tiny. There is a relaxed but caring atmosphere - with everything done with an eye for detail. Although I had booked we had to wait for a few minutes for our table as the occupants were paying there bill. We had a gin & tonic made with fresh herbs & served with canapés ( melon mousse on a cracker and mini chorizo sausage rolls - amazing) before sitting down for a late lunch. We ordered a selection of items which came on after the other - a highlight was black pudding cigarillos trickled with mayonnaise, also a broad bean, crispy spinach and egg dish with a balsamic dressing. All the flavours were clear and pronounced. The service was impeccable. I finished with beautiful caramel ice cream - with coffee came dishes of sweeties. We had a bill which was astonishing low for the quality (and quantity) of our meal - about 60 euros for 2. As you can tell - we loved it. Good Albarino too.

title_review: make a reservation and enjoy a great meal
review_preview: We came here around 8:30 which is early for spanish dinner.  However, they asked if we made a reservation (which we didnt) and said there was no room.  But if we wanted, we could try to get a seat at the high-top barside tables if...
review_full: We came here around 8:30 which is early for spanish dinner. However, they asked if we made a reservation (which we didnt) and said there was no room. But if we wanted, we could try to get a seat at the high-top barside tables if we came back in 20 minutes. When we came back, the waiter promptly showed us to the bartop and we enjoyed a lovely meal. The menu selection was vast. We enjoyed the croquettes (best we had in spain) as well as the porchini mushrooms, which had a bit too much balsamic. While eating, the restaurant completely filled up. If you want to eat there, make a reservation. Everything looked delicious.

review_preview: Our family of four (2 teenage sons) dined here last night on the first night of our trip to Spain. What a wonderful introduction to Spanish hospitality! Our waiter spoke excellent English, and graciously helped with our attempts to learn some Spanish. I had the...
review_full: Our family of four (2 teenage sons) dined here last night on the first night of our trip to Spain. What a wonderful introduction to Spanish hospitality! Our waiter spoke excellent English, and graciously helped with our attempts to learn some Spanish.  I had the hake, which was light and perfectly cooked. My husband had the lamb, one son had duck with crispy fried noodles, and the other ordered a cheese dish. Everyone enjoyed their meal. A nice surprise were the small samples of various tapas that were brought to the table, and a candy dish at the end. (We hadn't ordered dessert.) My sons devoured the first dish, and the waiter noticed and refilled it! All in all, a truly enjoyable evening. Thank you to them, and we hope to return!

review_preview: two years ago, we found this place and it was fabulous. Sometimes going back to a place you are left disappointed; but not here. Back in Madrid two years later and this place is still fabulous. A tiny place, good to make reservations. They don't...
review_full: two years ago, we found this place and it was fabulous. Sometimes going back to a place you are left disappointed; but not here. Back in Madrid two years later and this place is still fabulous. A tiny place, good to make reservations. They don't speak English, but are very patient with our attempt to speak Spanish....Muchas Gracias Jorge! Being a group of seven we tried nearly every tapa (I think we ordered 15). All were fabulous, particularly the croquettas, still the best I've ever had. Other standouts included a mushroom and bean saute surrounded by crispy spinach, small potatoes that were halved, and topped with a sauce. They were different than potatoes bravas. The goat cheese was excellent, as was the pate with the gin and tonic jelly. Wine list was wonderful, but if you go, get a Gin and Tonic (Larios 12 anos) -- sensational. So good that with tastes from my glass, 4 others at the table ordered them! 7E each seemed to be comparable price in the USA, however, upon arrival they were 3x the size of a gin and tonic in the USA.  This is a very local hangout...on the other side of Retiro than Sol. Bottom line, this place is 100% recommended. Go!

But no worries, the staff was very attentive and served us drinks while waiting. The menu consists of many traditional Spanish classics — inasmuch there is not much very exceptional on it. The salty cod was the best of the starters. The main courses (hake, artichokes with surimi noodles, papas, croquettes, duck vermicelli) were as expected: tasty but nothing out-of -this-world. The surprise came with the bill: for this quality, you would usually be paying a lot more, even by Madrid standards. Maybe that was one of the reasons so many locals were dining too.

review_preview: **This will be posted on Yelp, TripAdvisor, and Google because those are the places I look before picking a place**Incredible service!  I mean, the kind of service that made us look at each other and say "this would never happen in the states".  Our...
review_full: **This will be posted on Yelp, TripAdvisor, and Google because those are the places I look before picking a place** Incredible service! I mean, the kind of service that made us look at each other and say "this would never happen in the states". Our waiter was quick, kind, and knowledgeable about the dishes we wanted to try (mainly the paella). He spoke English, but engaged in our attempts to speak Spanish when we could. The paella is made from scratch, so it does take 25 minutes to arrive. In that time, he recommended we get a little something to munch on, but we told him we couldn't really afford to (we're students with very little money). Of course, when a plate of guacamole and plantains comes to our table, we became concerned and flagged him over to tell him we didn't order it. Do you want to know how he responded? "We've all been young once." The only problem is, I am now burdened with the task to pay it forward! What a genuinely kind gesture to two students looking for some good food. The food was more than that: it was delicious! We opted for Arroz Negro because neither of us had tried squid ink before. This would definitely be the place to try it out. The guacamole is different than what we have in the states, but it was a great appetizer before our HUGE dish of Arroz Negro arrived. We ate until we were full, and there was still more left. You are definitely getting at least your money's worth here. While paying, another waiter was really friendly, and talked to us about family he has in the states. He told us to hold on before leaving, and came back with two shots of Bailey's to send us on our way. This is the kind of restaurant that leaves both your stomach and your smile full. We will be back to enjoy it some more. Thank you for the great service!!

review_preview: I came here in search of the best paella in Madrid after doing some research on TripAdvior where it was ranked number 1. While I did enjoy the “surf and turf” paella that we had, it is my opinion that it could have been better....
review_full: I came here in search of the best paella in Madrid after doing some research on TripAdvior where it was ranked number 1. While I did enjoy the “surf and turf” paella that we had, it is my opinion that it could have been better. I found that (a) the chicken was cut into some small, unfamiliar pieces, (b) the seafood (shrimp, mussels and calamari) was somewhat over cooked and (c) it lacked the “socrito” (the crispy base that forms in the bottom of the pan) that good paella is known for. The rice and seasoning were very good. I suspect that the proteins were prepared separately and then added to each order resulting in them being over cooked and that the chicken pieces were cut small to facilitate quick cooking. I did notice the pan itself was well seasoned enough to allow for a socrito to form had there been less liquid in the pan and it had been allowed to cook just a bit longer. The earlier comment about the proteins being cooked separately and then assembled per order could have also contributed to the overall dish satisfaction. We did try some super outstanding eggplant chips that were drizzled with what was described on the menu as honey but was more resemblant of molasses. They were thin, flash fried morsels of deliciousness and worth a trip here for only those. We enjoyed a bottle of excellent rose wine that went well with both dishes. Our servers, Laura and Sheryl, were friendly and engaging. I also found prices to be very reasonable. Fun, hip and enjoyable food off a small street near the bustling Plaza del Sol.

title_review: Wonderfully modest restaurant but with excellent food
review_preview: GASTROMAQUIA SERVES EXCELLENT Spanish food done in unusual and original ways. There are lots of small dishes to chose from  (tapas or racoon style) but don't expect to find only the traditional items that carry the tapas label. We ordered the octopus with potato foam,...
review_full: GASTROMAQUIA SERVES EXCELLENT Spanish food done in unusual and original ways. There are lots of small dishes to chose from (tapas or racoon style) but don't expect to find only the traditional items that carry the tapas label. We ordered the octopus with potato foam, the seared goat cheese with honey and basil oil,the oreja (pigs ear- delicious) and the coquinas (little clams in a tomato-based sauce) and the thing shaved artichokes with balsamic vinegar and the tuna tartare. If you want traditional tapas you'll find some dishes like patatas bravas and some arroces, as well as paella but my advice is to be a bit adventurous. This is a small, modest looking restaurant in the gay-friendly Chueca district.Book ahead or you may be lucky if you turn up immediately after the place opens.

review_preview: I was a typical tourist in Madrid trying to find a decent restaurant for dinner,  among many to randomly choose from and hope for the best. My spanish is poor so wherever I went there would be an element of risk/adventure. I stumbled upon Gastromaquia...
review_full: I was a typical tourist in Madrid trying to find a decent restaurant for dinner, among many to randomly choose from and hope for the best. My spanish is poor so wherever I went there would be an element of risk/adventure. I stumbled upon Gastromaquia by chance while walking along Calle Pelayo. I am delighted I did. Every aspect of the experience was beyond my expectations..  My waiter Pablo spoke perfect english and was welcoming, knowledgeable and gracious. I am not a meat eater so that narrowed my options considerably. Pablo was able to recommend a coupled dishes which I tried (the guacamole with banana plantain chips, porcini croquettes and sautéed asparagus with parmesan cheese and balsamic vinaigrette. title_review: Completely over-rated restaurant with very salty food.
review_preview: We went to this place according to Tripadvisor ratings as usual - which normally result in a good choice. However this restaurant we think is definitely over-rated from 2.5 -3 star to 4.5 star. The place is pretty small with out of date decoration. Very...
review_full: We went to this place according to Tripadvisor ratings as usual - which normally result in a good choice. However this restaurant we think is definitely over-rated from 2.5 -3 star to 4.5 star. The place is pretty small with out of date decoration. Very limited choices of food and drink - only one beer option. Several dishes appeared on the menu are only served in winter time. Food is very slow - we waited for over 1 hour for the main dish after they served our food one by one - and slowly. The first two dishes are salty and the beer glass is so small. Then we waited for ages for pur main dish which is a seafood fried noodle which we expect to be less salty. However, this dish was extremely salty - even saltier than the most salty Kebab I have ever had in an Austria kebab shop. We can't even finish 1/4 of the dish because of its poor tasting and pure salty taste. Things happens but the waiter charged the salty dish for 2 persons in checkout which apparently it didn't write as "min 2 persons" like some other dishes. We pointed this out and the waiter became less patient and showed bad mood - even they let us waited so long with very little customers at that time. and the salty food - little poor beer. Then we pointed out how salty the food is - I definitely have high tolerance on salty food than my wife but even me never had this salty fried noodle before.  Anyway, this restaurant is not good at least for now in 2016 - you can try them and see how many stars they deserve - definitely not the 4.5 stars rating.

review_preview: Rosi La Loca - What a fun dinner we had at this restaurant with an unexpected menu!  This little place is difficult to find.  It’s on a tiny side street amongst many other small restaurants.  First of all, the decor makes you bust out laughing....
review_full: Rosi La Loca - What a fun dinner we had at this restaurant with an unexpected menu! This little place is difficult to find. It’s on a tiny side street amongst many other small restaurants. First of all, the decor makes you bust out laughing. There are huge bunches of colorful paper flowers all over the walls, which gives it a tropical (maybe Hawaiian) theme - but not. Maybe “The Little Shop of Horrors” theme - but not. The menu seems straight up, but when the dishes come out, our mouths drop in surprise and laughter.  When the Burrata salad comes out, there’s a huge white eyeball thing on the plate. It’s the size of a softball. Then, the waitress, and all of them have a strong sense of humor - must be a prerequisite to be hired at this restaurant - pulls out a huge hypodermic needle and injects the white ball with liquid green pesto. Hmmm, that’s kinda different. The shredded pork is between two soft Chinese bao buns in a V shape. They’re Chinese shredded pork tacos - that’s what they are but we are in Madrid! They are nicely seasoned and very tasty.  They didn’t have the baby squid that was listed on the menu so they substitute it for beef. The grilled octopus is good but could have a bit more flavor. There is mild chaos at Rosi La Loca but it’s all just fun.

title_review: Impeccable food, friendly owner and Chueca nightlife just outside

review_full: This place is all about excellent food. Just like the previous reviewers have already said, it's a small, simple place and the main focus is on the food itself. Last summer I visited here 3 to 4 times and had different courses each time - everything was very tasty and I was rather disappointed that I wasn't able to taste everything during my summer break in Madrid! The best part is that the owner - who is such a nice and sincere guy - was kind enough to provide tips on how to cook the courses myself! It's in the middle of bustling Chueca and the atmosphere is best described as "lively and loud" - just like in all the best places in Madrid. The restaurant itself is a reason good enough to pay a visit to Chueca. My favorites? Octopus (pulpo) with red wine!

He was really hospitable and the place was full of locals rather than tourists - didn't hear any english around us. He recommend a lovely bottle of Ribera del Duero wine for us to enjoy our meal with. We had ensalladilla (a cold cream potato salad) as lovely to start with on the warm evening. Then came a tikka mussel meal and then asparagus with balsamic and parmesan shavings. All delicious and left us full. However we still managed to squeeze in the mint mojito sorbet served in a cocktail glass which he filled up with rum - Amazing. Definitely get this no matter how full you are!

The guacomole served with banana crisps...........there was something about it that I can't put my finger on, just yummm. Curried octopus was not just excellent in taste but also in texture. There was more that we ate, but I cannot not say how good the pan fried goat cheese was, have it as a salad or just as entree it's awesome. Now that I have recollected my gastronomical memories lets talk about meager details. Place is small but cozy and full of trendy crowd (even at 4 pm in the evening, reservation recommended), service is excellent and prices, for the quality of food they serve it is very affordable. Our bill was about 120 Euros, including a bottle of wine, few more drinks and 6/7 dishes altogether, not a bad birthday meal, I would say.

review_preview: During a three week trip through Spain, this was one of our favorite and still most-recalled restaurants!  Gastomaquia is not a large restaurant so reservations are recommended.  We did not call in advance, but the friendly co-owner, Hugo, was happy to let us sit at...
review_full: During a three week trip through Spain, this was one of our favorite and still most-recalled restaurants! Gastomaquia is not a large restaurant so reservations are recommended. We did not call in advance, but the friendly co-owner, Hugo, was happy to let us sit at the bar and order our dinner and took the time to chat with us. The restaurant was filled with in-the-know-tourists. The menu is limited, but everything is fresh. Here, you will find classic tapas but prepared with a contemporary twist. For example, the classic pulpo a la gallega (octopus with potatoes) is presented as slices of tender octopus, sprinkled with paprika, on fragrant potato foam. The flavors are the same as the classic preparation, but the opposing textures in Gastomaquia’s version leaves you wishing this was the version they were serving across Spain! The restaurant is away from the touristy main roads and in a gay neighborhood filled (at night) with prostitutes, but is definitely worth seeking out for an unforgettable and friendly dining experience in the capital!

title_review: Cosy local place with great food and drinks at reasonable prices
review_preview: I booked a big family Sunday lunch here last month based on the reviews although I was nervous because we have different tastes and it can be hard to please everyone.  I also thought its location would let us have a nice walk through the...
review_full: I booked a big family Sunday lunch here last month based on the reviews although I was nervous because we have different tastes and it can be hard to please everyone. I also thought its location would let us have a nice walk through the Retiro Park to and from the restaurant either side of a good lunch, and follow it up with free entry to the Reina Sofia (from 1330 on a Sunday) or the Prado (1700-1900) . To my relief, everybody loved it although we skipped the museums afterwards because it was great weather and we all wanted to walk lunch off a bit. We liked the look of the starters more than the mains and so ordered large starter portions to put in the middle to share which the waiter was happy to help us sort out. The food was delicious and arrived at intervals so we each tucked into the same dish. It worked really well because the oven baked rice, one of their specialities, takes a while to prepare and arrived last. All of the food was of a very good standard, with the steak, "tigre" mussels and cheesecake really standing out. The drinks as well were fantastic as the bar specializes in cocktails so some of us had a few to finish our meal off along with a shared desert.  It's a small, modest but very local place so we were the only tourists, which my sister liked. Service was good and we always had something to eat or drink, which my other sister liked. The wine and cocktails kept my parents happy while my wife liked the general ambience. We were all very happy with the food and I was very impressed with the value for money. A very definite trip advisor hit!

title_review: Delightful spot with good food well priced
review_preview: We found this restauant on tripadvisor and went there our second night in Madrid. Because of the traffic patterns, we had to take a cab clear around Retiro Park, but Madrid cabs are not expensive.We arrived about 8:15, and of course most patrons were...
review_full: We found this restauant on tripadvisor and went there our second night in Madrid. Because of the traffic patterns, we had to take a cab clear around Retiro Park, but Madrid cabs are not expensive. We arrived about 8:15, and of course most patrons were still outside sipping wine. We ate inside and found it had a very pleasant, relaxed atmosphere. The waiter was friendly and helpful, and there was an Englsh menu, although all the other patrons seemed to be locals.  I ordered a pork loin, and was asked how I wanted it cooked. Somewhat surprised, I said medium well done. Then I remembered that in Europe the way they feed hogs does not carry any danger of trichinosis, so I did not need to have it well done. When it arrived, it was slightly pink, and very moist and tender, better that the somewhat dry pork we eat here. It was quite a treat. Edith also was very pleased with her vegetable dish and house wine, while I had bottled water that was slightly more costly than the wine - a not uncommon event in European restaurants. The total tab, with tip, was less than 50 Euros, and that made this not only a fine meal, but a bargain also. This restaurant is highly recomended. Not a Michelin Star establishment but absolutely fine for a very good, reasonable meal in a pleasant, local venue,

I think we would have enjoyed our mains so much more. I would still recommend this place and will return on my next visit to Madrid.

review_preview: If we were living in Madrid this would be one of our absolutely favourite restaurants. A smallish place with an almost family atmosphere and character, a purely Madrileno clientele (at least when we went, for lunch after a Sunday morning in Parque del Buen Retiro,...
review_full: If we were living in Madrid this would be one of our absolutely favourite restaurants. A smallish place with an almost family atmosphere and character, a purely Madrileno clientele (at least when we went, for lunch after a Sunday morning in Parque del Buen Retiro, itself not to be missed!) a welcoming, personable, smart and attentive waiter really good with advice about the food, including what would make enough of a meal - it was on his suggestion that we halved our order for the dish of boletus mushrooms and beans, one of the day's specials, that the two of us were going to share for a starter, and found he'd been absolutely right - and, most important, well-conceived and beautifully cooked food, stylishly served. My main course, of cod with tomatoes and hand-cooked chips with a pesto-like trailed across across the top, looked so much a work of art I felt almost reluctant to stick my knife and fork in it, and did so only after doing what I hardly ever do, take a picture, as attached. Snapped in low light it's unfortunately a bit fuzzy, but the dish was really delicious, as was my partner's food. When she and I asked to meet the chef so we could thank and congratulate him, he turned out to be a shy 21-year old, which made us all the keener to shake his hand, and wish him the best. He'll go far.

review_preview: Rosi La Loca- What a fun dinner at this restaurant!  This little place is difficult to find.  It’s in a tiny alley amongst many other small restaurants.  First of all, the decor makes you bust out laughing.  There are huge bunches of colorful paper flowers...
review_full: Rosi La Loca- What a fun dinner at this restaurant! This little place is difficult to find. It’s in a tiny alley amongst many other small restaurants. First of all, the decor makes you bust out laughing. There are huge bunches of colorful paper flowers all over the walls, which gives it a tropical (maybe Hawaiian) theme - but not. Maybe “The Little Shop of Horrors” theme - but not.  The menu seems straight up, but when the dishes come out, our mouths drop in surprise and laughter.  Burrata salad with pesto: When it comes out, there’s a huge white eyeball thing on the plate. It’s the size of a softball. Then, the waitress, and all of them have a strong sense of humor - must be a prerequisite to be hired at this restaurant - pulls out a huge hypodermic needle and injects the white ball with liquid green pesto. Hmmm, that’s kinda different. Shredded pork: When this comes out, there are two soft Chinese bao buns in a V shape with shredded pork filling. They’re Chinese shredded pork tacos - that’s what they are!  All of the dishes are nicely seasoned and Very tasty. Reservations are a must since this restaurant is very popular.

Everything so yummy we basically finished the whole thing between 2 adults and 2 children.  On the way out my husband accidentally broke a wine glass but the waiter said not to worry at all, human made mistakes with a big smile. Have not encountered such nice service and friendliness in other establishments in Madrid so far!

review_preview: Okay a bit extreme but, my best friends and I enjoyed a day trip from London to Madrid. I’d prebooked lunch here for midday but due to it taking an hour to get from the airport to the restaurant we arrived 20 minutes late. Nevertheless...
review_full: Okay a bit extreme but, my best friends and I enjoyed a day trip from London to Madrid. I’d prebooked lunch here for midday but due to it taking an hour to get from the airport to the restaurant we arrived 20 minutes late. Nevertheless the staff were welcoming and sat us at a table right at the front of the taverna. This place is very quirky and although the lunch menu was limited the food was delicious. We ordered the pork tenderloin, the Patatas wedges, mango chicken & ham croquettes. Due to the lack of choice we also order the surf & turf paella....and we definitely over did ourselves.  The food is incredible and the service is excellent. I can see why this restaurant is so highly rated and I’m so happy I chose to spend two hours of our 5 hours in Madrid in this lovely little gem of a taverna. On a side note, seating looks more comfortable downstairs although the decor isn’t quite as interesting.

review_preview: Had dinner here tonight.It’s located on a quiet side streetYes it’s Venezuelan but these guys can show the natives a thing or two!!We have been Madrid for most of the week dining out for lunch and dinner and have done a food...
review_full: Had dinner here tonight. It’s located on a quiet side street Yes it’s Venezuelan but these guys can show the natives a thing or two!! We have been Madrid for most of the week dining out for lunch and dinner and have done a food tour as well We have sampled many fine dining establishments and some not so good  These good folks show how to do it right for a modest set up. There is a smile and welcome from the barman as you enter. A waiter who is only too eager to please: none of the surly, hurried and harried and overworked standard Spanish waitstaff in sight. No “atmosphere “ and fighting for elbow room here. The tables are considerately spaced comfortably apart. And the food and drink and dessert are simply superb. Note that mixed drinks and dessert are not an afterthought here as in many Spanish restaurants:they were just wonderful!!!The wine list is well thought out and reasonably priced. Every single dish we tried was good to great so I will refrain from naming a few: I wish I could have tried them all!! We decided not to end our stay in Madrid with a fancy meal in a expensive restaurant and ended up with a real treat!!

Menu- both in English and Spanish.

review_preview: I lived in Venezuela and was encouraged to visit this Venezuelan restaurant by the rave reviews here.  Our first surprise came when reading the menu, which was just one cheaply plastified page and did not have anything special or different listed in it.  The menu...
review_full: I lived in Venezuela and was encouraged to visit this Venezuelan restaurant by the rave reviews here. Our first surprise came when reading the menu, which was just one cheaply plastified page and did not have anything special or different listed in it. The menu lacked personality, with a couple of Venezuelan tapas but the rest of the menu were just ordinary dishes you could find anywhere and not identified with any type of cuisine (Latinamerican or otherwise). They did not have a wine list either, so we had to blindly choose what to drink. Also, the wine we finally had was O.K., but ended up being 20% costlier in the bill than what the waiter had told me when I asked. As for the food, we asked for different dishes to share. Instead of bringing all the dishes at once, they would bring every dish with a minimum 20 minute difference between them, forgot one of the dishes we had asked for and would only tell us that they had run out of one of the dishes after we had been awaiting for over 50 minutes. The food taste and presentation were only acceptable by minimum standards and no different from what anyone without training would be able to quickly cook during a lazy Sunday. On the good side, their staff was friendly (although rather distracted and very slow) and they offer a complimentary coffee cream liquor with the bill (too bad that we had spent over two hours there already when the bill came in and could not afford to stay more time to enjoy the complimentary drink). We may have had bad luck in terms of the food quality and negligent service, but the other things in this review are serious objective shortcomings showing that in no way can this restaurant be ranked among the best in Madrid (was listed fourth best when we visited it).

title_review: Delicious food and friendly staff - can't wait to return
review_preview: This review is long overdue, but Cacao Restobar was my favorite restaurant I ate at while in Madrid. I stumbled across it by accident - I was browsing TripAdvisor after a visit to El Prado, looking for somewhere authentic that wouldn't be overrun with tourists....
review_full: This review is long overdue, but Cacao Restobar was my favorite restaurant I ate at while in Madrid. I stumbled across it by accident - I was browsing TripAdvisor after a visit to El Prado, looking for somewhere authentic that wouldn't be overrun with tourists. Cacao Restobar had very few reviews, so I figured it was a good bet. (Although I can see now they have tons of reviews! I think there were only about 8 when I went in early October.) I think I arrived in the restaurant at an odd time - it was only my second day in Spain, after all - because I was the only one there. The men who owned the restaurant were very friendly and the food was made from scratch and DELICIOUS. After I finished my meal, they began talking to me a bit and they told me they had only been in business for a few month. We talked for about 30 minutes and they told me about their plans for the restaurant and gave me a tour. They even complimented my Spanish, which I really appreciated! I told them I would come back in two weeks before leaving Spain, and as I walked by on my way to El Retiro, one of them saw me pass by and came outside to talk to me. I couldn't believe they remembered me. They are so nice!  Can't wait to visit again on my next trip to Spain!

review_preview: We wanted to try some traditional Spanish food while we were in Madrid - and this restaurant was definitely a good choice for that!Cocido is essentially when lots of meat and vegetables are cooked together for a long time to make a big stock....
review_full: We wanted to try some traditional Spanish food while we were in Madrid - and this restaurant was definitely a good choice for that! Cocido is essentially when lots of meat and vegetables are cooked together for a long time to make a big stock. The stock is separated and you get two meals: 1) Soup - with the stock and added fideos (a really thin noodle) - which is delicious 2) Everything else - they then bring out all the tender meats, chickpeas and lots of other vegetables (including cabbage/carrots/leek) It was a really hearty meal which I would say is the equivalent to an English roast - and we were super full! We also got a glass of Cava, croquettes and desert of our choice included in the price per person! The restaurant was very welcoming - and we knew it was a good sign when there was only the Spanish locals enjoying a meal there - would highly recommend if you want to eat something local.

title_review: New favorite in Madrid - Best cocktails in Spain
review_preview: Incredible. Fantastic service from people who truly care about your visit and appreciate your visit. Cocktails were authentic and delicious. Chris (professional bartender) created wonderful cocktails and Sangria utilizing fresh ingredients and infused liquors he makes himself. His passion really drives the bar portion of...
review_full: Incredible. Fantastic service from people who truly care about your visit and appreciate your visit. Cocktails were authentic and delicious. Chris (professional bartender) created wonderful cocktails and Sangria utilizing fresh ingredients and infused liquors he makes himself. His passion really drives the bar portion of the restaurant. Although we tried the original cocktails he created, his knowledge could probably create a special cocktail on the spot for you. The food was also on point. We had the Arepas, Patocones, Nachos and Fajitas. I recommend all! Fresh ingredients that were well prepared and very addicting. We couldn't stop eating them and left no trace of food in the end. Finally, the atmosphere. It's not your typical Madrid cafe/restaurant. It's a great blend of modern decor with some rustic pieces. Very accommodating. My wife and I couldn't say enough about how much we enjoyed our visit. Planned to stay 1-1.5 hours, but stayed 3 hours and only left because we truly couldn't eat or drink anything else. Bravo Cacao!

review_preview: Although I wasn't thrilled with my food experience in Madrid so far I luckily looked up the neighborhood advise in TripAdvisor and I found this brilliant place. The hosts really care you are having a great time at this bar/restaurant. And indeed I did although...
review_full: Although I wasn't thrilled with my food experience in Madrid so far I luckily looked up the neighborhood advise in TripAdvisor and I found this brilliant place.  The hosts really care you are having a great time at this bar/restaurant. And indeed I did although being by myself.  The served the best home made sangria i had in my life so I had to order two of them. They also treated me to try their home made coffee liquor. As there was a little photo shot going on I also had the chance to try their piña colada which was delicious too.  Let's talk about food: they ran out of the cheese thingy nevertheless I had their venezuelian pancakes with a great guacamole. As a main I had half portion of pork with caramalized onions and potatoes. Great taste indeed. Portion size are more than satisfying and taste extremely good.  Atmosphere very relaxing. Great music super comfy interior. All I have to say: muchos gracias a todos y hasta luego

review_preview: Thank you Trip Advisor and to those of you who submitted the reviews that directed us to this terrific find.  My partner and I were in Madrid for a week in October and went to Gastromaquia on our first night.  It's very conveniently located in...
review_full: Thank you Trip Advisor and to those of you who submitted the reviews that directed us to this terrific find. My partner and I were in Madrid for a week in October and went to Gastromaquia on our first night. It's very conveniently located in an up and coming and very gay neighborhood in Madrid. Do not be turned off by the plain exterior. The innovative tapas were the best we experienced during our trip and yes, the mussels were spectacular. We also experienced an amazing smoked salmon salad that was as beautiful as it was tasty. Be sure to save room for dessert ... the offerings are wonderful. The service was impeccable and the wine offerings were more value priced but delicious. We were prepared to use our Spanish translator installed on the phone but this was unnecessary since the owner described the menu in detail in English while at the same time explaining that was only a guide and that kitchen could work with us if we had something else in mind. Our only suggestion for improvement might be to lower the lighting level a bit.  We ate a several more upscale locations during the week and spent over twice the amount for far less inspired and in some case disappointing food. On our last day in Madrid we tired to return for a late lunch and were disappointed to find a change in hours that had the restaurant closed all day on Monday.

review_preview: Okay, don't let the humble decor and simple menu fool you. The dinner we had there was perhaps the best meal we had in all of our 2 weeks in Spain. Our waiter, Carlos, one of the owners and a native of Venezuela, spoke almost...
review_full: Okay, don't let the humble decor and simple menu fool you. The dinner we had there was perhaps the best meal we had in all of our 2 weeks in Spain. Our waiter, Carlos, one of the owners and a native of Venezuela, spoke almost perfect English and was very attentive. When I first looked at the simple menu, I was a little worried, but Carlos explained the menu to us and made several recommendations, each of which was better than the last. The plantain appetizer was melt in your mouth good, and the pork tenderloin was the best I ever tasted, hands down. He recommended a dessert that was soon memorable.  And the entire thing was under $40 Euros for 2! So not only was the food incredible, but the price and value virtually unmatched.  You must go to this unassuming place and enjoy a palate enticing meal!

review_preview: This restaurant is lovely and it's very interesting. They only serve cocido, which is the typical dish of Madrid. It's a prix fixe of 29 Euros and it's all you can eat. When you arrive at this typically decorated restaurant, they seat you and immediately...
review_full: This restaurant is lovely and it's very interesting. They only serve cocido, which is the typical dish of Madrid. It's a prix fixe of 29 Euros and it's all you can eat. When you arrive at this typically decorated restaurant, they seat you and immediately serve you a glass of Cava (Catalunya's answer to Champagne). Then they bring you delicious homemade rolls that you can dip into a plate of also delicious tomato sauce. This is followed by a chicken noodle soup that is brought to you in a clay pot, which keeps it hot. I can assure you that few of you have tasted a better chicken noodle soup. Then they bring the garbanzos - chickpeas along with boiled potatoes, cabbage, carrots and other goodies and on another plate chicken, tocino, chorizo, black pudding. If you manage to polish off all of that, they bring you more at no extra cost. This is followed by a choice of several typically Spanish desserts, coffee and a chupito - liqueur. They also provide you with souvenir bibs to save your clothing from their delicious soup!!  Well worth the visit!
