title_review: Fantastic! Great cocktails, great food - loved it so much we went back!
review_preview: We loved everything about this place, visiting twice at different times of day during our short stay in Madrid. The staff are polite, friendly and helpful, but without being overbearing, and the decor is modern and tasteful. When we visited there was a really good...
review_full: We loved everything about this place, visiting twice at different times of day during our short stay in Madrid. The staff are polite, friendly and helpful, but without being overbearing, and the decor is modern and tasteful. When we visited there was a really good acoustic Ibiza sessions soundtrack playing in the background which we really enjoyed. We chose to have mojitos, which are our favourite cocktails, and of which we consider ourselves a good judge having been drinking them for years in many different countries. We were thrilled to discover that the cocktails were lovingly and expertly prepared with fresh ingredients, plentiful alcohol and they tasted superb!  We had the house red wine with our meals, which was great too, and it didn’t stop there because the food was delicious too. The first time we visited was for or evening meal. My fiancé had a lovely king prawn risotto and I had a Mediterranean vegetable stack with goats cheese sauce, which although called something different to this, was explained well so I knew what to expect. Both dishes were served hot and fresh, and I was smiling the whole time I was eating it. We both had chocolate brownie with chocolate ice-cream for dessert which was not only generous in terms of the portion size, but also good on taste with a nice crispy shell housing soft decadent brownie within. Two mojitos, two glasses of red wine, two mains and two desserts set us back just €56.50 - incredible value for such a delicious meal. We were so impressed with our evening meal that the next day before we left Madrid, we couldn’t help but pop back to Cacao again to grab another couple of those fabulous mojitos. We also shared some nachos which were among the best we’ve had. This time the bill came to €25.90. We can’t recommend this fantastic restaurant enough! Despite the huge choice of places to eat in Madrid, if we go back there we shall return to Cacao for sure.

review_preview: I visited Rosi La Loca with a large group of friends on a hen do. I had booked in advance and the restaurant was very responsive, including sending us a set menu due to the size of the group. This was ideal as it was...
review_full: I visited Rosi La Loca with a large group of friends on a hen do. I had booked in advance and the restaurant was very responsive, including sending us a set menu due to the size of the group. This was ideal as it was a set price which made settling the bill much easier at the end of the meal! Our table was located in the basement of the restaurant while upstairs had smaller more intimate tables.  The starter course was a selection of 3 tapas dishes to share which were wolfed down by the group. The main was steak, and the restaurant was also able to accommodate the two vegetarians in our group with a delicious alternative. The dessert was individual cheesecakes and also went down well. We were pleasantly full by the time we had finished as well as slightly merry as the set menu included drinks during the starter and main course.  The staff were brilliant and very accommodating of our slightly high spirited group. The restaurant itself was decorated in a vibrant floral style.  I wouldn’t hesitate to eat here again next time I am in Madrid.

title_review: The most incredible food in Madrid!

We got 5 tapas dishes and we were absolutely stuffed so we would recommend 4. We had the Potatus bravas(A must have!!!), the potato and fried egg, croquettes(amazing), honey roasted goats cheese(again, an absolute must have!) and the squid(wouldn't recommend this).  Although we didn't have the paella, I saw a Spanish couple share it and they were nodding away and looked very impressed. Honestly incredible food, incredible service. I would love to come back next time we're in Madrid and we will be recommending to others.

title_review: falling in love with food again
review_preview: “Not knowing what to expect means not having expectations” however even if had been informed of this place I cannot imagine how it could have failed. Six guys descend of this rather poky provincial looking “feeding hole” in the back streets of Cheuca on a...
review_full: “Not knowing what to expect means not having expectations” however even if had been informed of this place I cannot imagine how it could have failed.  Six guys descend of this rather poky provincial looking “feeding hole” in the back streets of Cheuca on a typical Friday night. My initial impression, once inside, was not positive especially as you hit a tall bar and column/pillar in front of my clear vision. The young lady was nice but spoke pigeon English. Very swiftly the magic commenced. A rather dashing waiter came to collect us from the back of this elongated eatery even as she continued to try and pronounce Daniels’ Dutch family name…the waiter had noticed our arrival and heard the name; the table was already and set for our pleasure. Im already impressed .All nice and airy after meandering our persons through the little tabled area we had the nice spacious area at the back. Another two ticks! Enter Hugo, fluent in English, this Catalan was not betraying his roots but reinforcing excellent Spanish hospitality. He articulated almost every item in detail from the starter until we stopped him due to the fear of eating each other as we got hungrier and hungrier. He chose a selection of items and we also had the aid of a couple of bottles of white wine which he also chose. The dishes arrived on time and with excellent presentation. The dishes pleased both the eye and palate and we did re order a couple of items.  We spoke of going back but were too scared similar to making that second date phone call too soon incase it goes pear shaped! In plain English ….this place is fantastic. The service was akin to my experiences at the Gordon Ramsey’s Hospital Road and other 5 stared restaurant…ie fantastic and the food was to go back for. Well done guys looking fwd to revisiting in December.

review_preview: I went to this restaurant with a relative after reading the glowing reviews on TripAdvisor and on other Internet blogs. And I am glad to say it lives up to the hype!To start with, the owner, Hugo, is extremely friendly and personaly greeted every...
review_full: I went to this restaurant with a relative after reading the glowing reviews on TripAdvisor and on other Internet blogs. And I am glad to say it lives up to the hype! To start with, the owner, Hugo, is extremely friendly and personaly greeted every guest in the restaurant. He translated the entire (Spanish only) menu for us and gave us plenty of time to choose (though a good sign was that the menu was not overly extensive) To start with we had the pan seared goats cheese with honey, which was unlike anything I've ever had before...delicious. The patatas bravas were also tasty (and came in a very decent sized portion). Next came the octopus with a light creamy potato foam - again a unique, delicious experience for me. We also had the asparagus with Parmesan and balsamic vinegar, of which the latter had a subtle sweetness to it, enhancing the flavor of the dish. Our mains concluded with a skewer full of tender, succulent iberian pork pieces -it was so good I was about to ask Hugo what the marinade was! Finally we finished off with a yummy vanilla ice cream and strawberry sorbet with coke syrup plus a mojito sorbet - a refreshing way to finish off a fantastic meal I highly recommend this restaurant to any traveller passing through Madrid. Though there are a lot of tourists in the shop, it is definitely NOT your usual tourist trap and is very reasonably priced. I would gladly return here if I visited Madrid again. Thank you to Hugo and his staff for a fantastic dinner!

title_review: Great Food, Great Service, Great Value
review_preview: Hugo is an excellent host, come for the food, not the ambience but Hugo's warmth and genuine hospitality is an example of a fine attitude toward providing excellent food in a winning combination of price and quality. Food is inventive, fresh, delicious and generous. Basically...
review_full: Hugo is an excellent host, come for the food, not the ambience but Hugo's warmth and genuine hospitality is an example of a fine attitude toward providing excellent food in a winning combination of price and quality.  Food is inventive, fresh, delicious and generous.  Basically no wine list at this stage but phone ahead and see if you can take your own. booking recommended. We highly rate this as a super dining experience based on small menu and knowledgable passionate staff - the right way to have a sustainable restaurant.  We wish Hugo all the best and hope this restaurant hits #1 in Barcelona. 80 Euros very well spent for fois gras and a separate fried goat cheese - an outstanding combination, best Russian Salad EVER, superb Galecian styled octopus with a foamy twist, a delicious duck dish, a salted dark chocolate foamy mousse and a minty mojito frappee for dessert finished the evening perfectly and we would definitely go back. Meal included a couple of cavas and the house Rioja. Thanks Hugo, you rock!!

review_preview: We read the good reviews & decided to check out this little restaurant since it was on the street we were staying. We arrived 8.45pm on a Monday night & were the first diners to arrive. Hugo (the co-owner) greeted us warmly & explained the...
review_full: We read the good reviews & decided to check out this little restaurant since it was on the street we were staying.  We arrived 8.45pm on a Monday night & were the first diners to arrive. Hugo (the co-owner) greeted us warmly & explained the whole menu (which was in Spanish) and gave us suggestions, which we happily took on board. The meals came out quickly & were displayed beautifully. We ordered the guacamole & banana chips (very tasty!), the goats cheese (blew our mind) the octopus with potato foam (very unique as we had not tried foamed potato before!) and deliciously seasoned pork skewers with hummus. We finished off with the famous mojito gelati (very refreshing). Hugo and another friendly waiter (sorry we didn't get his name) were very attentive & encouraged us to try some Spanish shots of liquor. Which we happily tried. We were so impressed with the food & service that we returned 2 nights later to try the rabbit, goats cheese salad, the mussels, potatos bravas and finished with strawberry, vanilla & coca cola gelati. Plus more shots yet again! Thank you to Hugo, chef & staff for a very delicious & memorable meal in Madrid :) J&J (Sydney, Australia)

review_full: I really agree with all other reviewers who said that the restaurant doesn't look like much from the outside, but if you just forget about that and step in, you're in for a real treat! The menu is only in spanish, but the staff speak English and are willing to translate it for you. Infact, I think this was intentional in order to give them a chance to chat with you because they are extremely firiendly. The menu is small (as with many restaurants we've been to in Madrid) but what they cook, they cook very nice! I would recommend their goatcheese with honey, octupus plate, and mussels with Masala! As 3 people ordering appetizers and mains to share we paid 70 euros in total.

title_review: Excellent food, great service....A Must Try
review_preview: We visited Madrid to celebrate our 1 year wedding anniversary.  We were unsure where to eat and searched Trip Advisor for suggestions.  All the other reviews were spot on!We walked by around 9:00 and there was no one in the restuarant.  I kept forgetting...
review_full: We visited Madrid to celebrate our 1 year wedding anniversary. We were unsure where to eat and searched Trip Advisor for suggestions. All the other reviews were spot on! We walked by around 9:00 and there was no one in the restuarant. I kept forgetting how late everyone eats dinner in Spain. Defintiely don't judge the food by what the restaurant looks like from the alley. The walls are white and it is really small, but the food and service make up for it. Our waiter was so nice and helpful and made some great suggestions. The menu is in Spanish but he helped explain what each dish was. We had the guacamole, squid, and rabbit. All so different but delicious! This was our most expensive dinner in Madrid, but worth it.

review_preview: Pitched up here relatively early last Monday evening (1st October 2018) and the place was already busy. Luckily for us a table for 5 was found downstairs in the restaurant.Initially service was slow; we were left with the menu for about 15 minutes -...
review_full: Pitched up here relatively early last Monday evening (1st October 2018) and the place was already busy. Luckily for us a table for 5 was found downstairs in the restaurant. Initially service was slow; we were left with the menu for about 15 minutes - not an extensive selection, but as we were to find out what this restaurant did produce it produces to an excellent standard! Drinks and food was ordered in due course: two selections each.  I would describe the food here as "big tapas" - each dish is delivered as it is cooked, but is a lot more substantial than usual tapas dishes. We ordered between us the pork, beef, Taranaki chicken and burrito - all were fantastic!  This was definitely our best meal during our four day stay in Madrid. With drinks the bill was just overall €65, which was excellent value and after the initial blip the service was prompt and cheerful!

We don’t eat meat and there were nice interesting fish (smoked sardine blow-torched at the table) and veggie choices. Trying to be a bit different, non-traditional, possibly getting towards gimmicky (cheese ‘injected’ with pesto), but it all tasted great, and we had three things we’ve never had before which is always a bonus. Then warm brownie and ice cream and apple tart with ice cream, which made a very happy end to a very enjoyable meal. On our first, short trip to Madrid, just the kind of place that make the trip really enjoyable which we could only have found with TA.

review_full: We made reservations here based on the amazing reviews from other trip advisor members. We are so glad that we did! The food was absolutely delicious, the service attentive and friendly, and large cocktail menu besides a nice wine list. We ordered several appetizers to share - baked mussels, beef with goat cheese, artichoke and eel and prawn . All were tasty and nice to share. We ordered rice with vegetables, baked hake, oven rice with duck confit and skirt steak. Not a bad entree in the group. We would order each again. Their tiramisu was fantastic, best we had while visiting Madrid.  We will recommend to our friends who will visit Madrid in a month.  The servers were friendly and made recommendations after asking our preferences. Their advice for both the food, wine, and cocktails were spot on! We would eat here again in a heartbeat.

review_full: Based on TA reviews, wy wife and another couple decided to have dinner at restaurant. The place didn't seem terribly appealling at first sight, but the waiter who greated us, Joaquin, was charming and explained how each of the dishes on the menu were prepared. He served us hors d'voures that were delicious. Then an assortment of phenomenal croqretas unlike any we have ever tasted. The main courses of pork, lamb and merluza were among the best any of us have eaten. Plates were served with delicious papas souffed. We weren't sure if the desserts would reach the level of excellence, but in fact the creme brulee and chocolate cake and ice cream were the best we've eaten in Europe. Madrid is the last stop on a European tour, and the we ate this evening was by far the best. Kudos to all!

title_review: Creative and Unique Tastings in Madrid
review_preview: Gaytan offers a creative and unique tasting menu experience that follows the style of other many-course European tasting menu restaurants with a Spanish flair by chef Aranda. The food was delicious, service very good; we overall very much enjoyed the experience. Price was very reasonable...
review_full: Gaytan offers a creative and unique tasting menu experience that follows the style of other many-course European tasting menu restaurants with a Spanish flair by chef Aranda. The food was delicious, service very good; we overall very much enjoyed the experience. Price was very reasonable (we were only charged 80 euro per person for what seemed to be the long tasting menu listed as 132 euro online). Definitely deserving of the Michelin star. First I will note that they were able to accommodate a diner with celiac disease who did not get sick after the meal. We simply made this note on the reservation; many of the courses were naturally gluten free, and for those that were not they were able to make small changes to exclude any gluten. We visited Gaytan on a Saturday night. The restaurant is small - just 5 or 6 tables which all surround the large completely open kitchen area where you can observe the 3 chefs at work (head chef Javier Aranda did not seem to be there the night we visited). Surprisingly only 3 of these tables were full on a Saturday night so the service was extremely good, 3 waiters for only 3 tables with 7 guests in the restaurant. We were not given a choice of menu but it seems we were given the long tasting which ended up being 14 courses total (though surprisingly the bill revealed only an 80 euro/person price at the end!). The spring menu featured a variety of mushrooms, starting with some mushroom based appetizers, then vegetable based courses, followed by fish, and then meat finally followed by desserts. The wine selection seems good and we had two good glasses.

We were seated in front of the station where the made our master pieces. Best if all, Javier was there making our meal. We requested a birthday cake for our dinner. It was expensive for a little piece of nugget. It was the price of a bottle of wine! But heck, it was a special occasion! I was able to chat a little and tell the chef how much we enjoyed the experience and have a photo taken with him. How delicious was the meal? Well, no matter how well I described it you, this is something only your have to taste yourself!!!! My favorite was the Iberico Pork which is fed only by acorn. It was just amazing. The sweetness and tenderness was beyond expectations!

review_preview: VILA BRASIL is the right spot to eat a delicious tasty brazilian feast or to just enjoy cocktails at the bar or terrasse. One is located in calle Ibiza and the other one in calle Puenteareas. I can tell you that I could close my...
review_full: VILA BRASIL is the right spot to eat a delicious tasty brazilian feast or to just enjoy cocktails at the bar or terrasse. One is located in calle Ibiza and the other one in calle Puenteareas.  I can tell you that I could close my eyes and feel like if I was back in Brazil eating the delicious dishes my Brazilian mother in law used to cook.  Each type of meat has its own flavour,  all being  extremely tender. The vegetarian/vegan  buffet is also  very flavoury. We enjoyed a lot eating there!! Before I forget, make sure to start with a Caipirinha, the Brazilian famous cocktail. My favorite one is the kiwi Caipirinha. If you are not a cocktail person, this one will make you change your mind! We are genuinely glad to have discovered that restaurant, and  will definitely go enjoy the rodizio meat buffet (14€) once more before leaving Madrid. Restaurant highly recommended! Ciao Ciao VILA BRASIL es el lugar ideal para comer una deliciosa comida de brasil o simplemente disfrutar de cócteles en el bar o en la terraza. Uno está en la calle ibiza y el otro en calle puenteareas. Puedo decirte que puedo cerrar los ojos y sentir que si estaba de vuelta en brasil comiendo los deliciosos platos que mi madre en la ley usaba para cocinar. Cada tipo de carne tiene su propio sabor, siendo todo muy licitador. El buffet vegetariano/vegetariano también es muy sabroso. ¡disfrutamos comer allí! Antes de que me olvide, asegúrese de empezar con un caipirinha, el famoso cóctel del brasil. Mi favorito es el kiwi caipirinha. ¡si no eres un cóctel, esto hará que cambies de opinión! Estamos realmente contento de haber descubierto que el restaurante, y sin duda disfrutará de la carne de rodizio buffet (€14) una vez más antes de dejar madrid. ¡restaurante altamente recomendado! Ciao Ciao

title_review: One of the highlights of our trip
review_preview: This place was one of the highlights of our trip for both food, drink and service. The menu offered several vegetarian options which we were not expecting (having to have been flexible with our diets generally in Madrid) and turned out to be delicious, in...
review_full: This place was one of the highlights of our trip for both food, drink and service.  The menu offered several vegetarian options which we were not expecting (having to have been flexible with our diets generally in Madrid) and turned out to be delicious, in particular the vegetable lasagna and aubergine chips. They also offer many fish and meat options as well as many side dishes and traditional Spanish wares. The pudding we chose, a melted chocolate dish was delicious and we had to try several items off the cocktail menu! The drinks are presented in a fun way and the food presented professionally and with flair. The hostess was kind enough to let us change tables due to the corner table not being very comfortable for my very tall partner and we were seated in the bright and cosy downstairs.  The place was full of locals which we always take the be a good sign and we were waited on fantastically by two charming and attentive waiters who appeared to be twins! They were very funny and improved the experience even more.  We spent considerable time here that evening and ordered considerable amounts of items also due to the pleasant atmosphere and lovely staff. It made it up there into our favourite experiences as we left our hunger satisfied and smiling.

review_preview: The very location of Gaytan is dramatic. It is almost hidden, off the main street, up an alley. We arrived there after a seriously long taxi ride from our hotel in Plaza de España. In the dark, their little unlit sign was invisible. We were...
review_full: The very location of Gaytan is dramatic. It is almost hidden, off the main street, up an alley. We arrived there after a seriously long taxi ride from our hotel in Plaza de España. In the dark, their little unlit sign was invisible. We were beginning to think our taxi driver had played a trick. But a friendly local walked us down the alley.  The room is very attractive. The kitchen is the stage. The discreet array of well spaced tables are arranged in a broad semicircle around the stage. Chef Javier stands center stage. Though quite young, he has an imposing presence. He is intense and takes in everything going on in the kitchen and in the audience. His kitchen brigade is alert, precise, and not very relaxed. When you arrive at Gaytan you are invited to have 1 of 2 set menus. Then you begin your first bit of theatre. A series of liquids to 'awaken' your palate, along with a brief description of what will follow. From boxes you are asked to select a pearl, a piece of silk, or something else. That seemed to define what was going to arrive for you. Interesting. Sort of. You are told that you will travel on a journey of dishes from China,through Mongolia, Nepal, Persia,India Italy, France and finally Spain. Those responsible to carry out the explanations have a big responsibility to keep it interesting, fun, and understandable. Our waiter was earnest, but his English was marginal. He didn't seem to get it when we didn't understand him. He just motored on with the spiel. Things felt hokey at times. The opening dish was a drama. Chicken,roasted corn, mushrooms and vegetable infusion with a Beijing duck taco. A small serving with remarkable intensity and complexity. From Mongolia came Horse Mackerel Tartare, Cured Yolk, and Black Garlic Fluid. This arrived in a small plastic bag. Scissors were provided to cut the bag. You then squeezed the contents onto your plate. It was extremely delicious just the same. Most of the remaining dishes ranged from very good to just OK. The theatrics of the presentations too often overshadowed the pure food flavours we were seeking. We opted for the wine pairings. Our waiter turned out to also be the sommelier. We had some pleasant wines, but they often did not fit the dish. There was a randomness to what arrived. This is after all a fairly pricey evening. More could be expected here. So overall a mix. It is a novel experience. The theatrics were interesting at times. Some of the food tastes were exotic and fascinating. The wine service was lacking. Once may be enough.

review_preview: Upon arrival everything appeared perfect. We started off the "Journey" with some palate cleaners before being seated at our table. These were very unique and delicious and followed a fun story line which continued at the table. We chose to opt for the smaller tasting...
review_full: Upon arrival everything appeared perfect. We started off the "Journey" with some palate cleaners before being seated at our table. These were very unique and delicious and followed a fun story line which continued at the table. We chose to opt for the smaller tasting menu with the traditional wine pairings. The first course, which was a soup inspired from China, was very delicious in flavor but very overwhelming (as well as filling) due to its bold flavors and thick texture in comparison to the serving size. Another issue we experience was overcooked meat on some dishes. The fish on one dish was so tough and rubbery it was left on the plate after one bite. The tasting menu, however, had 3-4 plates that were delicious. The best plate on the menu was the pulled duck taco dish. The rest were very disappointing, lacking balance and harmony in it's flavors and textures. The flavors sometimes were very bold and too strong for the amount you received in the dish. The wine pairing was disappointing to say the least. While there were a few good wines the sommelier selected, none of which paired well with the courses presented, either underwhelming or overwhelming the dishes. The story behind the dishes in traveling through different countries was fun and unique. There were several unique utensils and plates. The service was good but it seemed that they were rushed, not "in synch" with each other, and at times lost. There seemed to be a lot of pressure to have everything "perfect" which seemed to create a stressful atmosphere for the staff as well as it's guest.  Overall, there were several good dishes (especially the duck taco), however it is not enough for us to come back for another visit.

title_review: Correct Cocido at a correct price, and nice staff
review_preview: We came here for Cocido a couple of times, and I must say the cocido is correct. Nothing out of this world but a good place to taste this typical boiled concoction. It is not difficult to make a correct cocido, to be honest, is...
review_full: We came here for Cocido a couple of times, and I must say the cocido is correct. Nothing out of this world but a good place to taste this typical boiled concoction. It is not difficult to make a correct cocido, to be honest, is all about the ingredients, and here the ingredients are good. It is nice for families, as the place is packed on Sundays with several generations of the same family sitting at the same table. As a tip, they have two sittings per Sunday, and you better book in advance, letting them know what sitting you would prefer (If I remember correctly either 1.30 or 3.30pm).  Unfortunately I can't comment about their a la carte as I go there for the Cocido!

title_review: Favourite restaurant in my trip to Madrid
review_preview: I visited Madrid for 2 weeks to attend Spanish school, and ate in a variety of good restaurants while i was there. However my favourite was, without doubt, Recreo.The chefs are extremely talented, and the food was interesting and exciting.  Both food and wine...
review_full: I visited Madrid for 2 weeks to attend Spanish school, and ate in a variety of good restaurants while i was there. However my favourite was, without doubt, Recreo. The chefs are extremely talented, and the food was interesting and exciting. Both food and wine were outstanding value for money. The staff were professional and friendly, welcoming me back like an old friend on my second visit, and Manuel in particular has a real talent for making his guests feel valued. I wish I'd had the opportunity to eat at Recreo more often, and will make a point of returning when next in Madrid.

review_preview: Gaytán reaffirms the Michelin-star, traditional fix tasting menu model. The restaurant is beautiful and chic - few desks turned to the central piece of the room, where the open kitchen is located (with the best exhaustion system I have ever seen). It is quite the...
review_full: Gaytán reaffirms the Michelin-star, traditional fix tasting menu model. The restaurant is beautiful and chic - few desks turned to the central piece of the room, where the open kitchen is located (with the best exhaustion system I have ever seen). It is quite the experience Gaytán offers - from beginning to the end. You will see liquid nitrogen being used to harmonize cocktails, the Lamb Experience composition will also blow your mind (after they tell you what it was you ate, part of the experience :)) However, I did feel the restaurant to be a little cold and not so friendly. I did not feel very comfortable - not sure if it was the fact that we had to stare at the staff the entire time, or the tight timing we had to actually have our meals.It is also really tricky to find, it is located at a side entrance of a parking lot and we only found the sign indicating entrance long after the meal ended. It is also a bit tricky to leave if you have a late dinner given the location of the restaurant is a bit outside the main hubs and it took us about 15 minutes to get a Taxi. Gaytán defintely deserves its stars - impecable Menu and super criative dihses that will be food for the eyes as well! Having said that, I think a warmer touch to the service could get it to the next level for me.

title_review: Very disappointing compared to our last visit
review_preview: I lived in Spain briefly in 2016 and often came to Rosi La Loca, specifically for their delicious paella. We were always impressed with the food, their service, and the whimsical ambience of the restaurant.  I was excited to return upon my most recent visit...
review_full: I lived in Spain briefly in 2016 and often came to Rosi La Loca, specifically for their delicious paella. We were always impressed with the food, their service, and the whimsical ambience of the restaurant. I was excited to return upon my most recent visit to Madrid, but found our experience underwhelming at best. First, the food was much worse than it used to be. The paella did not have even a hint of saffron flavour, and the rice was overcooked. The croquetas were overly creamy and undercooked.  The service was good: the staff was friendly and fast, but almost suspiciously fast (we were in and out in 50 minutes, much shorter than the usual 2 hour dinner to be expected in most European restaurants), and we felt rushed out of the restaurant.  It seems to me this once-authentic Spanish restaurant has compromised quality in order to rake in the tourists (who love fast service and usually probably cannot tell the difference in authentic Spanish food).  Tldr: If you want an authentic Spanish meal and dining experience, look elsewhere.

review_preview: First things - thanks very much to all - due to a last minute change of plans for an event we (3 of us) had the whole restaurant to ourselves!!  Brilliant - but must have been a pain for them and costly.  Service levels excellent...
review_full: First things - thanks very much to all - due to a last minute change of plans for an event we (3 of us) had the whole restaurant to ourselves!! Brilliant - but must have been a pain for them and costly.  Service levels excellent - despite it being just the 3 of us and assuming all the staff were probably thinking of being elsewhere.  Great decor - spacious and relaxing interior.  We took the long tasting menu - 10 countries and 16 was courses. Just slightly too much for me as I was struggling slightly towards the end. A journey based on the old silk route from China to Spain stopping off in various countries along the way to experience their take on local food during the period of the silk trade.  All dishes extremely well presented with colour, textures layout etc. Some dishes worked better than others - a great mini Indian meal (4 courses served together) and also a dish fro Italy of an inside- out crunchy ravioli excellent and very flavour some, but others not so well- this fish course for example, the purée didn’t match with the fish and the fish itself was not so tasty.  Overall highly enjoyable and much changed since my previous visit (2 years ago?).  Would be a 4.5 if I could record that. Just slightly undone by a couple of the less successful dishes. Definitely worth seeking out.

title_review: Superb dining experience. Great interior design, delicious food and excellent, friendly service.
review_preview: Last year we went to Javier Aranda's restaurant La Cabra, which was excellent, so we were eager to try his newest venture, Gaytan, which also has a Michelin Star. We were not disappointed as we had a superb dining experience.The restaurant was a little...
review_full: Last year we went to Javier Aranda's restaurant La Cabra, which was excellent, so we were eager to try his newest venture, Gaytan, which also has a Michelin Star. We were not disappointed as we had a superb dining experience. The restaurant was a little bit tricky to find as it is actually located down the side of a building that fronts Principe de Vergara and carries the same street number, being, 205, as it would appear do several other buildings. It is located very near to Concha Espina metro station. The interior design is innovative and creative with the open kitchen being in a semi circle and the wooden dining tables also being curved with the diners both on the same side of the table facing the kitchen almost as if you are watching a theatre production with the entertainment being provided by the chefs. We had the Dining Experience tasting menu which was comprised of an amuse bouche, 6 tasting snacks, 6 mains, a pre-dessert, dessert and a fantastic little covered wagon that contained the petit-fours at a cost of Euro100 per head. All of the dishes were beautifully presented and extremely tasty. Gaytan also had gluten free bread. Wine list was extensive with a number of reasonably priced bottles as well as top of the range. Service was excellent, friendly and efficient, with all of the dishes being explained. Fabio, in particular, was first class. Lunch took about 2 and a half hours however we didn't notice any real length of time between dishes, they all seemed to be well spaced. Would dine here again in a heart beat, particularly as I now know where it is located.

It is visually a work of art and the flavours are unique, fresh, surprising and above all tasty. The wine pairing was also well chosen and the service was impeccable. Can't find anything I would have improved. We will continue going to la cabra but I sense this location would be my favorite of the two. I see a 2nd star in the future .... bravo!

review_full: This is a casual, friendly little restaurant, that provides food with a very nice twist, for a very reasonable price. The two of us shared 3 starters and one main: the guacamole was excellent (although served a little too cold) with banana chips. The tuna tartar was amazing, with just a taste of mild curry. As for the tikka masala mussels - wow! Just for those, I will come back as soon as I can. We shared a 'main' of risotto with oxtail which also was perfect. The staff was very friendly, managed a good English, and was helpful at recommending the wine (also very reasonably priced). We didn't wait at all - in fact, the service was perfect - but this restaurant also Cather for larger groups, and it might be a good idea to go there early. The most difficult part is to choose.... But the staff will be happy to help.

title_review: Based on One Star and the Price it gets a Five.
review_preview: The concept is good the delivery failed  but we can live with that.  The problem was our waitress  had memorized the  story but her command of English was lacking (not her fault and she does not have to cater to English speaking clientele)  but to...
review_full: The concept is good the delivery failed but we can live with that. The problem was our waitress had memorized the story but her command of English was lacking (not her fault and she does not have to cater to English speaking clientele) but to get the point of the story line was difficult. Outside of that the food spoke for itself, service was excellent and the open kitchen and the kitchen staff were superb. The World Journey Tour was pretty good in that I have been to all the cuisines touched. They took an Asian country and put Javiar's version on it and he was pretty good. It is a restaurant on the cutting edge and will refine itself along the way. The Sous Chef was a"take no prisoners" woman and the staff was for the most part quite serious about what they were doing. Secondly, after meal service they scrubbed that kitchen down cleaner than anyplace we ran into. Spotless. That attention to detail says a lot and shows in the food.

review_preview: We selected the silk road menu (10 courses).Unfortunately you have only a set menu (either 10 or 14 courses) which is intriguing, but to a certain element also limiting the choices, as you cannot select from a menu.The journey is interesting and you...
review_full: We selected the silk road menu (10 courses). Unfortunately you have only a set menu (either 10 or 14 courses) which is intriguing, but to a certain element also limiting the choices, as you cannot select from a menu. The journey is interesting and you need to take it really as an experience in a discovery park where people at the table describing the plates are trying to tell you a story that is somehow limited. So the storyline comes out a bit awkward and out of context. Without further elaborating on this, the culinary experience is great. You are sitting in front of the kitchen where in a half circle or as an "amphitheatre" they prepare your dishes. Looking at these chefs is amazing: all their movements are professional, precise and you can feel their skills. All different delicacies are incredibly presented and stunning. Of course within the 10 courses that they served us, we had our preferences: the ravioli from Nepal and the pasta from Venice, have been amongst our best picks, whereas the fish from Persia and the cheese from Greece, probably the ones we found more dull and less intriguing. The restaurant has a nice set up, although the atmosphere could be a bit warmer (you feel like being in an operating room). Overall a great experience.

title_review: For the first time in my life I ate in the same restaurant twice in a row!
review_preview: We were working at the nearby Auditorio and reserved twice in a row here. There is no printed menu. There are at least a dozen people working in the fantastically beautifully custom designed open kitchen. the 77 euro menu begins with a series of 5...
review_full: We were working at the nearby Auditorio and reserved twice in a row here. There is no printed menu. There are at least a dozen people working in the fantastically beautifully custom designed open kitchen. the 77 euro menu begins with a series of 5 amuse-bouche presented on handsome ceramics, then a series of fish dishes and finally a meat dish, in this case venison. this is top of the line conception and presentation and worth every penny. the flavour of every dish was peerless. Really enjoyed everything immensely. very competent service. try one of the Toro wines for a red. I will admit that even the hispanophile and hispanophone obsessed gourmet that I am had trouble understanding their explanation in English of every dish, as they are complicated. There is no written menu. For the second evening the amuse-bouche were the same but all the mains were different and all fantastic. There was some pike with roe and a great slice of tuna neck in a tasty sauce. Ask for a table in front of the kitchen for a great show. next time I'm in Madrid I'll be back!

review_preview: Last minute booking after the kids went away for the night.  Down a side street with no expectations.  First thing on entry was the wine cooler full and smoking.  Coats taken and the to our table. Very cleverly designed - round tables that split into...
review_full: Last minute booking after the kids went away for the night. Down a side street with no expectations. First thing on entry was the wine cooler full and smoking. Coats taken and the to our table.  Very cleverly designed - round tables that split into 2 and arranged as in a jazz club / Caberet with the stage obviously the kitchen which all could see- around the large mushroom like pillars.  We took the long tasting menu (only options a long and shorter version). For the evening it was to be honest 1 - 2 plates too many, but maybe that is age.  All dishes presented immaculately with great attention to detail and fully explained. Mixture of textures and flavours all working well together. Many interesting deconstructed dishes.  A fantastic risotto - but without any rice! Great fish dish cooked on the table in front of us and a very good lamb dish.  A couple of things didn't quite work - baby squid nice but not to the level of the rest. But the rest fantastic.  A real eye opener and much more imaginative and surprising that expected. Taking things to another level and underlying the Madrid restaurant scene.  Get in there now before it becomes too well known with long waiting lists and a need to reserve months in advance as in certain other Madrid eateries!!

title_review: GREAT experience to share as a family!
review_preview: This was our family's first experience going to a Michelin-star restaurant and it was a winner! Back home in the States as a family we have been enjoying watching shows like 'Chef's Table' together. Honestly, I had always thought that sometimes the architectural food I...
review_full: This was our family's first experience going to a Michelin-star restaurant and it was a winner! Back home in the States as a family we have been enjoying watching shows like 'Chef's Table' together. Honestly, I had always thought that sometimes the architectural food I would see in those shows looked a little pretentious and wasn't sure how the food would actually taste. So, I told my boys to appreciate the attention to detail and passion with which the food was created.  THE FOOD BLEW US ALL AWAY!!  The talented and rising star young chef, Javiar Aranda was working hard all night right near us and he is able to infuse incredible and contrasting flavors and textures into dishes in a way that is totally surprising and satisfying. We had a full degustation menu that lasted over three hours with the wine pairings that highlighted for us what an incredibly delicious and well-priced national treasure the wines are in Spain. I was hopeful that my youngest ( age 11 ) would enjoy the meal, along with his "foodie' big brothers. He ate everything and thanked me (!) after each course ( of which there were 17 ) for bringing him there. For all of us, we were so satisfied we weren't hungry for practically the whole next day and we have had a lot of fun discussing the meal and every aspect of it. I read a recent review where the person got there early and had to wait for the restaurant to open. We had the same experience at 9 p.m. and loved the fact 1. that in Spain that is when a restaurant is opening and 2. that the Spaniards can be so relaxed. It made us get out of our normal New York heads and to be there in more ways than one. And though this is not an inexpensive meal, the value of this meal with it's creativity and quality of food and wine served is tremendous.

review_preview: We really enjoyed eating here, the food, the service and the experience were all really enjoyable though by the end the flavours were beginning to merge!The staff were great and explained each course but their accents speaking in English meant we lost quite a...
review_full: We really enjoyed eating here, the food, the service and the experience were all really enjoyable though by the end the flavours were beginning to merge! The staff were great and explained each course but their accents speaking in English meant we lost quite a lot of their explanation and had to ask each time for different parts to be repeated before we got it! The kitchen staff are watching you, sometimes we felt to see if you liked their concoctions but more usually to get the timing of the next course spot on, which they did. They were true professionals. The kitchen itself is very modern and you sit around and facing it though there are some places where viewing proceedings would be more challenging from behind a pillar - try and reserve a good view, it's worth it. We have the full tasting menu which was extensive with small snacks before dishes with chicken satay, scallop, white beans, mushroom soup, sweet potato with a mussel sauce, crab, red mullet, Peruvian beef, wonderful lamb and two delicious sweets (apologies for my pitiful descriptions but I just recall the headline ingredient in each dish!). There was a beautiful selection of bread served as well which could have been disastrous as they offered and we would have eaten more but sensibly declined. The presentation and detail was fantastic and included not only the food but the serving dishes and cutlery which came in all sorts of different shapes and sizes. Gaytan's selection of wines accompanied the food superb and I would recommend having this rather than choosing one or two wines yourself. The wine pairing cost 50 euro's and dinner 101 euro's each. Thanks to other contributors who provided help on finding the restaurant. The entrance is at 205 Principe de Vergara and down an alleyway that is on the left hand side of a car park. There is a smartly dressed doorman waiting to receive you at the from door when you arrive. There is a sign on a street lamp-post that says "Gaytan" so you shouldn't miss it. When we were ready to leave, we asked the staff to get us a taxi and when one was there, they told us so there was no waiting around outside. A great and very memorable experience and I hope we will be back sometime.

We also had the potatoes with spicy sauce, shrimp with garlic & octopus. The potatoes were hand cut wedges, perfectly cooked & delicious. The spicy sauce was not my favorite so we did the mayo ketchup instead. The garlic shrimp were a few large ones with plenty of slices of garlic in a flavorful oil. So fresh & full of flavor. My favorite garlic shrimp In Madrid. Octopus was fresh & cooked well. We also tried the tinto or red sangria but was not as tasty as the white.

title_review: Over-rated and over-promoted by Trip Advisor
review_preview: We visited this restaurant because of it's rating at 16th out of 9,529 restaurants in Madrid and quickly realised it had been seriously over promoted in Trip Advisor listings.  It's not a bad restaurant but the décor, surroundings, ambiance, service and presentation of food cannot...
review_full: We visited this restaurant because of it's rating at 16th out of 9,529 restaurants in Madrid and quickly realised it had been seriously over promoted in Trip Advisor listings. It's not a bad restaurant but the décor, surroundings, ambiance, service and presentation of food cannot catapult it to this level in its peer group in Madrid as it just isn't that good. The surroundings were shabby and the walls were pine clad. Whilst I can cope with that the service was indifferent and occasional. There was no table cloth, the mains arrived before the starter plates were removed and we were asked to keep our cutlery from one course to the next. Service was slow and the staff were difficult to attract. We would have had more drinks had the service been more efficient; we might even have had a sweet course had we been asked but by then we had tired of the place, having cleared our main courses onto an adjacent table ourselves as the staff weren't going to clear the table. We had the arepas degustacion as a shared starter between the 4 of us. We are familiar with Venezuelan food and they were fine but nothing special. After a long wait, our mains of pabellon, fajitas and salmon plancha arrived and their common theme was they were all cold. As we had been waiting and the hour was late, we got on with the cold food which again was OK but nothing spectacular, apart from the obvious, that it would have tasted better had it been hot.  At no point did any staff ask us how we were enjoying our meal, if there was anything further that we needed etc. We had to go to the front desk to get and pay for our bill which with Perrier, 2 rum cocktails, Sangria Cava and the food described above, was over 100 euro's. Will we be back - no! The really annoying part was that expectations failed to be fulfilled which is entirely the responsibility of over promotion by Trip Advisor and the way their system works.

review_preview: This was possibly the best meal we ever had.  It was absolutely amazing.  We went here on a Tuesday night so the restaurant wasn’t packed. The chef/owner knew we did not speak Spanish well, so he explained all the items on the menu.  We started...
review_full: This was possibly the best meal we ever had. It was absolutely amazing. We went here on a Tuesday night so the restaurant wasn’t packed. The chef/owner knew we did not speak Spanish well, so he explained all the items on the menu. We started with the guacamole, which I am generally not a fan of, but it was amazing, and I loved it. Next we had Mussels Tikka Masala. We have never had Tikka Masala reimagined this way, it was fantastic. Next we had the Octopus with Potato Foam. This was the best part of the meal. It was absolutely delicious, we’ve never had something like this. If you go, make sure you try this. The final dish we had was the lamb stuffed with goat cheese, another great dish. My wife is not a big fan of lamb, but she loved this. For dessert we had White Chocolate Foam with Raspberries. The foam was just the right touch. It was simply delectable. The chef then surprised us with a 2nd dessert, Mojito Sorbet, which was a great way to end the meal. This was a fantastic meal and the chef was great. He actually spent time talking to us.

review_preview: Well recommended by Trip Advisor reviewers, and rightly so. A nondescript frontage - the sort of place you would walk by if you didn't know better. Inside is small and quite basic - but immediately friendly. The owner translated and explained every menu item with...
review_full: Well recommended by Trip Advisor reviewers, and rightly so. A nondescript frontage - the sort of place you would walk by if you didn't know better. Inside is small and quite basic - but immediately friendly. The owner translated and explained every menu item with us. There were four courses to choose from, and they were served up one at a time on a single plate for the four of us to share. Our first choice was guacamole with plantain chips, second was orange and honey salad, third was octopus in a creamy sauce and fourth was sliced rolled pork. They were all totally delicious and full of flavours. We finished with a dessert each, I had mojito green sorbet - knockout ! Service and food top-notch. All for 115 euros for four people including 2 bottles of wine. Don't go to Madrid without going to this charismatic restaurant.

review_preview: Our last night in Madrid and came here after reading the reviews on trip advisor and chowhound. Difficult to locate (we walked)  and when we did find it were not sure if we had arrived at the right place (small, few tables etc..). Luckily we...
review_full: Our last night in Madrid and came here after reading the reviews on trip advisor and chowhound. Difficult to locate (we walked) and when we did find it were not sure if we had arrived at the right place (small, few tables etc..). Luckily we decided to stay. We immediately hit it off with the owner (I'm a little bit of a foodie) and when we mentioned we have a house in Miami Beach and that one of our favorite restaurants there is Pub Belly, turns out the owner of Pub Belly is one of his best friends....well the night was made. The food is exceptional, tapas portions easily shared between two people. Unique though is the Chefs modern interpretation of classical Castillian and Catalonian dishes. The guacamole/bananas..wonderful way to start the dinner, the croqueta boletus (light and creamy, beautifully fried), the pulpo plancha (nicely prepared and very delicate) and finally the pincho de secreto...just wish we could have had more. To top it off the people at the table next to us had the mejillones and thet were so enthusiastic that we had to try them (despite my dislike for mussels). Phenomenal, couldn't leave a drop of the sauce behind. We ate too much but despite the abundance of food the bill wea very reasonable,90 euro. Can't say enough of the owner, knowledgeable, enthusiastic, friendly, someone I'd like to meet again, hopefully soon at the Taberna.

review_preview: Based on TA reviews, we Tried to get a reservation by phone, couldn't get through so we left a message and hoped for the best. We waited in the somewhat sketchy neighborhood for it to open. Doors didn't open till 8:30, and we found that...
review_full: Based on TA reviews, we Tried to get a reservation by phone, couldn't get through so we left a message and hoped for the best. We waited in the somewhat sketchy neighborhood for it to open. Doors didn't open till 8:30, and we found that they did not have us written down, but even though they were booked full, since it was Valentine's Day, they allowed us in. Thank goodness. The owner broke down the entire menu for us in English and stopped us when he thought we were ordering too much. My husband liked the guacamole and plantains the best and i thought the octopus was amazing. The staff and owner were attentive and the dishes came out in perfect time, one after the other. The owner told us his philosophy that he cares more about producing good food that a smaller number of people would enjoy rather than okay food for a larger mass of people. it may me harder to make more money that way, but he is passionate about the food. In the end, the bill was very reasonable and they do except credit cards. Gastromaquia made our night, thank you.

review_preview: I love this place and will be going back for the third time in one month, for three reasons.Extremely friendly staff who explain specialities, how their food is cooked and answer any questions you have in Spanish or in English. If you don't finish...
review_full: I love this place and will be going back for the third time in one month, for three reasons. Extremely friendly staff who explain specialities, how their food is cooked and answer any questions you have in Spanish or in English. If you don't finish anything, they ask you why and if everything was ok.  Also this is a restaurant so of course the food had to be great. Cacao Restobar is meant to serve up Latin American dishes and it does arepas and fajitas very well. There are also typical Spanish options like patatas bravas and flavorful risotto cooked to al dente. Instead of my usual vino tinto or tinto de verano, I was recommended the sangria and the reason became quite clear soon after. My friend and I shared tres leches which was super milky (as it should - the best tres leches I have had in my life was at Porto's Bakery in Glendale, California, and this comes extremely close, possibly at par.) Last but not least, the location is super convenient for anyone before or after museum visits, eg, Prado, Reina Sofia, Thyssen, or Sol even. But if you want to eat during typical Spanish meal time, you should definitely book in advance. One quick tip: wifi only works in the front by the bar, almost doesn't work at all in the back section. Buen provecho!

review_preview: I visited Rosi La Loca Taberna on January 21, 2017. The service provided by Jordan our server was great.  And Jordan spoke English so that was helpful.  The potato wedges were very tasty and the mango wings were excellent.  The chicken paella (I have a...
review_full: I visited Rosi La Loca Taberna on January 21, 2017. The service provided by Jordan our server was great. And Jordan spoke English so that was helpful. The potato wedges were very tasty and the mango wings were excellent. The chicken paella (I have a shellfish allergy so can't have the traditional seafood paella) was great. All the food was delivered to the table hot and delicious. One note is that they do not accept American Express, so like the tv commercial says, "Bring your Visa card" :-)

title_review: Way overrated; Not one of our best experiences in this great food town
review_preview: We've spent a month in Spain, 6 days in Madrid, and had some outstanding food. We cannot include our experience here in our list of good restaurants however. It's a small place, with minimal decor. Yes, the owner is very friendly and accommodating, and spoke...
review_full: We've spent a month in Spain, 6 days in Madrid, and had some outstanding food. We cannot include our experience here in our list of good restaurants however. It's a small place, with minimal decor. Yes, the owner is very friendly and accommodating, and spoke good English. We ordered 5 items; Three came out one right after another. Our first course, the Fois, came out so cold that we had to wait and let it warm up some, to enjoy (and spread) it. The goat cheese salad was quite good, as was the tikka masala mussels - though the sauce was very salty. The Pulpo (octopus) we would pass on again, too much cream/cheese and the secreto Iberian skewers were flavorless and overcooked. Where they really lack is in the service; there's the owner explaining the menu and taking the orders, and one other person staffing the room. Each time our next course came, the last course still remained, and we had to shuffle our plates to make room. Additionally, we were left with the plates from the previous course, sauces and all, and we had to ask for new fresh plates to enjoy the next course. I thought after we asked the first time that he would be responsive for future courses, but we had to ask again after each course. Bottom line, it was average food at above average prices ($100US) with poor service, in a nutshell. To top it off, there was a couple with a young child two tables away from us, who was climbing on the table and making a lot of noise in the restaurant, causing us (and other tables around us) to be annoyed. We mentioned this to the server at the beginning of the meal, and again once more, and we heard others commenting as well. His response to us was that he couldn't do anything about it. Don't get the impression that my experience was skewed by the child; yes, that was an annoyance. But I am commenting on the food and the service here, and for my last night in Madrid, this trip, I was sorely disappointed in the food and the service...and I wouldn't return nor recommend it to my friends.

review_preview: Taking advice of all you trip advisor reviewers was the right thing to do. I had an amazing meal here and would go back again in a heartbeat if I could. As I was dining alone it's a shame that I couldn't try out a...
review_full: Taking advice of all you trip advisor reviewers was the right thing to do. I had an amazing meal here and would go back again in a heartbeat if I could. As I was dining alone it's a shame that I couldn't try out a lot of the menu due to portion sizes and cost but the waiter was absolutely fantastic helping me to translate the entire menu for me. Service like this is a rare breed and is to be applauded. I opted for the banana chips and guacamole. Hands down the best guacamole I've ever had. Stunning. Then I had some spicy potato dish which whilst certainly tasty left me regretting choosing this over other dishes on the menu. Then I had the lamb skewer. I've eaten a lot of meat in my time but oh my, it tasted so good and the meat was just melting in my mouth. I couldn't say no to desert and wasn't let down by what I can only describe as a plain chocolate soup dotted with crunchy breadcrumbs, olive oil and a tiny amount of salt. Again, tasted fantastic, every ingredient earning its place in the dish. I just wish I could go back again and try the restaurant highlights. Destined to stay in the top 5 if they carry on producing food like this. Oh and get there early. By 9pm it was full.

Sara was our server and she helped us choose our tapas so we didn't over order. We had porcini croquettes, baked goats cheese with honey and a paella with lobster. All of which were very good and cooked to order, the pace of the meal was spot on. To finish one of the young male servers advised a mojito sorbet with mint, it was exactly what we needed to come away without being over full but if you want more here you just order it. We loved the place as it was full of locales and we got there about 20:00, by 21:00 the place was packed and buzzing. A smashing experience, thanks to Sara and the team.

title_review: What an absolute gem this place is!
review_preview: We arrived in Madrid on 13th Oct - should have known (Friday the 13th and all that!)  as I ended up in hospital having stitches in my knee after coming off a Segway! Anyway, this wonderful bar was next door but one to our apartment...
review_full: We arrived in Madrid on 13th Oct - should have known (Friday the 13th and all that!) as I ended up in hospital having stitches in my knee after coming off a Segway! Anyway, this wonderful bar was next door but one to our apartment - perfect limping distance! Without exception all of the staff were welcoming, friendly, helpful and so nice. Fantastic inspirational cocktails made by Chris - try the smoked bourbon/orange infusion - it is amazing! Carlos, Edgar and Edicsson - who manage and own the bar were always around and all so friendly. There is a lovely atmosphere to the place with fantastic and well thought out decor for the bar area and the 2 other eating rooms. Every area was exceptionally clean and comfortable. All of the food we had was great quality and freshly made. It really did help to make our short holiday fantastic - to the extent that we intend to return and stay close by again so we can make this a regular place to eat or drink each day. Absolutely top notch!

review_full: We decided to try Cacao based on TA reviews and were pleased with the results. There is a printed English menu available. The waiter/owner was just sitting down to his own meal when we came in, so we sat and enjoyed a glass of house wine before ordering. His meal looked so good, one of us decided to order it. It was meal of cuttlefish and tiny octopi, extremely tender, with some small potatoes in a mole sauce. This and several dishes are available as half-orders. The other order was pulled pork with fried plantains, rice, fried egg, and black beans. Everything was delicious. We had no trouble getting a table around 7:30 but other folks kept arriving and the place started filling up. We are only sorry we are not in Madrid any longer, or we would plan to go back to try other items on the menu.

List of surprises when you get the bill: - The bread and service is 1,50 euros per person. - Some people get water from the tap and some others bottles of water. - Deserts are from around 6 - 7 euros, but they are not included in the menu, so you don't know how much they cost until you get the bill. A simple cheese cake is 6 euros. - The octopus suddenly became 1 euro more expensive in the bill than in the menu. - The mojito sorbet was delicious, but it was 7 euros. The food is not bad and they can have some nice things, but we felt completely cheated. At the end we paid almost 55 euros (2 people).

title_review: Great Food & Service, Decor Needs A Bit Of Work....
review_preview: I went here for dinner my 2nd night in Madrid and had a great meal! I dined solo and the owner, Hugo, made me feel very welcome and kept me company by chatting with me and helping me practice my Spanish. I ordered the guacamole...
review_full: I went here for dinner my 2nd night in Madrid and had a great meal! I dined solo and the owner, Hugo, made me feel very welcome and kept me company by chatting with me and helping me practice my Spanish.  I ordered the guacamole with plantain chips, the octopus in cream foam with paprika and then a chocolate foam/mousse dessert with toasted bread crumbs & sea salt - everything was absolutely mouth watering! Hugo also brought me some lime sorbet with rum on top to finish the night - it was like a delicious frozen mojito - Yum!  The decor / lighting is the only thing that I think needs some work. The lighting is very bright and the walls are almost completely bare. It would be nice to see some warmer lighting and maybe some artwork on the walls, a few candles on the table, etc. The place just seemed very sterile to me (almost like being in a doctor's office). That being said, I didn't go for the decor, I went for some amazing Spanish food and that's exactly what I got!!

review_preview: Four young partners opened this lovely restaurant about 6 months ago and it is a winner, from the very warm welcome from Carlos (one of the partners), to his guidance through the menu and the attentiveness of his partner, also Carlos.Everything is made "in...
review_full: Four young partners opened this lovely restaurant about 6 months ago and it is a winner, from the very warm welcome from Carlos (one of the partners), to his guidance through the menu and the attentiveness of his partner, also Carlos. Everything is made "in house" and it shows. Fresh, fresh, fresh. The homemade sangria, served in a mason jar was garnished with cinnamon stick and lots of fruit. Delicious. Service was fairly swift, but we were never rushed. Yummy was the Arepas degustacion and the Patacones, a pulled pork tapas starter. Then the beef and chicken fajitas were served garnished with sour cream (their version, very good), avocado cream, grated cheese and chopped tomatoes and onions. All very filling, but don't miss the desserts. We shared brownie and homemade ice and lemon pie. Along with the check came a delicious, complimentary chocolate liquor. All in all a very worthwhile evening, and did I mention the entire bill was 50€. Treat yourself and GO!

title_review: One of my favorite Madrileño secrets
review_preview: The Chueca street just outside brims with colorful weirdos of all sorts, and the façade of dinky Taberna Gastromaquia honestly does little to stand out in the midst of the rainbow flood. It took insistent TripAdvisor gushes to coax me in the first time, and...
review_full: The Chueca street just outside brims with colorful weirdos of all sorts, and the façade of dinky Taberna Gastromaquia honestly does little to stand out in the midst of the rainbow flood. It took insistent TripAdvisor gushes to coax me in the first time, and the experience was so overwhelmingly positive that I've made it one of my very few "regular" places in the city. The pulpo, the pulpo! Get the octopus with potato foam; it alone is enough to warrant repeat visits. The impossibly creamy guacamole also shines, but the true star here is owner Hugo, who was absolutely born for this line of work. My visits have been spaced out with multiple months in between, and the guy's not only recognized me warmly each and every time, but also recalled my HAIRCUTS. His English is outstanding, and he's an impeccable host. I've been here with my mother, I've been here with dates, I've been here with great old friends. Taberna Gastromaquia is a Madrid gem, comfortable and creative, great value for the money, and deserves much more attention that it gets (even if that makes it trickier for me to snag a last-minute Friday night table!).

title_review: Madrid's Best Flavors with Zero Pretension
review_preview: Dont be fooled by the simple decor of this brightly lit sliver of a restaurant.  It represents the very pinnacle of Madrid's food scene right now.  Pure flavors, cooking perfection, creativity without conceit.  And your host may have just found a way to sqeeze you...
review_full: Dont be fooled by the simple decor of this brightly lit sliver of a restaurant. It represents the very pinnacle of Madrid's food scene right now. Pure flavors, cooking perfection, creativity without conceit. And your host may have just found a way to sqeeze you in without a reservation (a feat that i wouldn't bet on though) yet he welcomes you like an old friend. Eat here if you can! The warm goat cheese appetizer with a carmelized honey crust and the most equisitely colored green (basil based?) sauce is a starter that alone makes a visit here worh it and memorable. The failings of tourist aimed croquettes around the city are revealed by the ethereal lightness of the mushroom croquettes that despite their appearance nearly float in your mouth. And just when you think you have enjoyed octopus everyway possible, this kitchen comes up with a paprika magic preparation that people apparently flock here for. But the famed pulpi dish shouldn't eclipse the other outstanding main dishes like the rabbit. The place is so simple looking you will probably think you couldnt possibly have found the right restaurant. But you have, and if you are dining there as a visitor to this city, you will have found a hidden gem of Madrid.

title_review: Best Food on Our Spain Trip
review_preview: Hugo translated the entire menu to us.  The menu was large; it had about 5 things under the four sections - Starters, Salads, Veggies, and Meat. We were told that each dish would be plenty for the two of us and it was.  We ordered...
review_full: Hugo translated the entire menu to us. The menu was large; it had about 5 things under the four sections - Starters, Salads, Veggies, and Meat. We were told that each dish would be plenty for the two of us and it was. We ordered the red wine, bread, Guacamole with plantain chips, Orange Honey salad, grilled asparagus with parmesan cheese, and kabobs. We were very full but Hugo suggested we at least share the mint sorbet with rum, we were glad we did! He then served us 2 shots (free)! One was a red berry and the other some herb – did NOT like the berry but we did like the other. Everything was so GREAT we had to come back for another night. We ordered the orange salad again, Foie Gras, caramelized goat cheese with honey sauce, and BBQ ribs. It was all excellent other than the ribs. They were very tasty but we are Texans so we really should have skipped BBQ Ribs. Their specialty is the mussels, and octopus but my husband won’t eat either of those!

title_review: Great food in a small and cozy place
review_preview: Great dinner night, I went w/ my wife for our 8th anniversary celebration.Ups:Great food, we ordered tuna tartar, massala mussels (mejillones) and octopus in potatoe cream... Mmm delicious, I just remembered and wanted to taste all again.Great service, very nice people serving...
review_full: Great dinner night, I went w/ my wife for our 8th anniversary celebration. Ups: Great food, we ordered tuna tartar, massala mussels (mejillones) and octopus in potatoe cream... Mmm delicious, I just remembered and wanted to taste all again. Great service, very nice people serving the tables, and I'm not sure if we were lucky or the kitchen had us timed, but each time we finished a dish, the next was ready in our table. Good quality-price ratio Downs: There was no English, nor French menus a la carte, and the place is in a very touristic neighborhood so if you decide to try it, you'll probably end up guessing what you'll eat, because they have very gourmet options and no good English skills to explain you that the dish is deer for example, exactly what happened to the folks next to our table, they were watching all the dishes to decide what to order, so a good recommendation for the restaurant is to invest in a menu translation option. You can reply this message, I can help you with that.  We went with very high expectations (actually we reserved via phone) we were downsided by the fact that the restaurant allows street sales (peddling) inside, no good for your image, except if you have some sort of ONG support campaign though... Because of that I'll give it a 8 over 10. Overall very good experience. Enjoy!!

I am a bit picky about my wine but I was pleasantly surprised by some of their suggestions (a white wine from Lanzarote).  I am definitely going back and bringing more friends to discover this place and highly recommend it to anyone looking for great inventive food, served with a smile in a fun neighborhood.

review_preview: my husband and i had just had a fight, the pouring rain was soaking through my favorite coat and the hotel umbrella was doing little to help keep me dry, but lunch here put a smile on my face that will be there for a...
review_full: my husband and i had just had a fight, the pouring rain was soaking through my favorite coat and the hotel umbrella was doing little to help keep me dry, but lunch here put a smile on my face that will be there for a while. we were asked if we had reservations when we entered. yikes, we didn't, but as it turns out, there was one table left for us. (note, this place is small and popular so if you come, call ahead.) lunch began with a bowl of pickles with a bit of an asian flair. sesame oil and a sprinkling of black and white sesame seeds had my non beet loving husband and i fighting over the bits of beet buried under the olives, carrots and more traditional cucumber pickles. my husband speaks spanish, but our quadralingual waiter was more than happy to translate the menu for me. in fact, the whole team of waiters was friendly and fantastic. we started with a lovely salad with bits of black truffle then moved on to rice with chicken, iberian pork, leg of lamb, then a fantastic olive oil cake. a plate of chocolates came with the bill. the plates were small but satisfying, each with a deep soulfulness that left us wishing there were restaurants like this back in new york. despite the glum mood we had when arriving, we left hoping every meal on our month long trip would be this good. in fact, i'm pretty sure this place is going to be hard to beat.

review_preview: My boyfriend and I had 4 tapas which was perfect for the two of us. We ordered steak tartare, goat cheese with basil and honey, patatas bravas and Ibérico pork skewers, since our waitress recommended these.The food was served very fancily and (mostly) cooked...
review_full: My boyfriend and I had 4 tapas which was perfect for the two of us. We ordered steak tartare, goat cheese with basil and honey, patatas bravas and Ibérico pork skewers, since our waitress recommended these. The food was served very fancily and (mostly) cooked to perfection. I found the steak tartare was just a bit overpriced and would not order it again. Same with the pork skewers, they were just not special enough to wow me... But maybe our expectations were also too high after reading so many raving reviews on TA. The service was very attentive and friendly at all times. They also had no difficulties speaking and understanding English, which wasn't always the case in Madrid. The only reason I only give 4 stars instead of 5 is because of the price. It was not that expensive, but in Madrid you can find such wonderful restaurants and places to eat for a lot less €€€. One last tip: If you want to go to Gastromaquia, definitely make a reservation.

review_preview: After going through about 30 restaurants to find something that was open on a Monday night, I came upon this place.  I'm glad I did!  It's quite unassuming when you walk up but the food was YUM.  The potatoes were cooked perfectly and even though...
review_full: After going through about 30 restaurants to find something that was open on a Monday night, I came upon this place. I'm glad I did! It's quite unassuming when you walk up but the food was YUM. The potatoes were cooked perfectly and even though they were called "spicy" potatoes, they weren't. Get the half order...trust me. My two favorites were the goat cheese (freaking amazing) and the mojito sorbet with a shot of "something" in it. We had some great wine as well. The biggest bummer for me was that we couldn't have paella or anything with rice because the (one) guy who makes their rice was sick. Strange to hear, but I guess in these smaller places, they have one guy who does that one thing. The server was really funny and friendly and even called us a cab when it started raining and we didn't even have to ask! The atmosphere could be spruced up a bit, but the food was delish and prices were great!

review_preview: Despite reserving, it was disappointing to find on our arrival that our table had been accidentally given away. The waitress was very apologetic and took us through to the bar where she then gave us some complimentary guacamole as an apology. Whilst this was a...
review_full: Despite reserving, it was disappointing to find on our arrival that our table had been accidentally given away. The waitress was very apologetic and took us through to the bar where she then gave us some complimentary guacamole as an apology. Whilst this was a nice touch, we ended up waiting well over an hour to finally be seated which was rather frustrating - it then took a long time for anyone to come and take our order. The food itself was very good - we ordered the octopus and asparagus to start, before moving on to the lobster paella. The octopus was very rich, but the asparagus was delicious, as was the paella (although the lobster meat itself was somewhat limited). We had a nice bottle of rioja, but we particularly enjoyed their 'special recipe' sangria - so delicious and refreshing, and highly recommended.  Overall it was a very good meal and not a bad price overall, however the service was rather a disappointment. Whilst the staff were very friendly, they seemed to just be running round all over the place and all rather chaotic (despite having 4 waiters in what is only a small restaurant). The restaurant was busy and so I definitely recommend booking (just hope they don't give your table away!). Aside from the service, we thoroughly enjoyed our meal here and really enjoyed the food and sangria.
