review_preview: This fantastic little place was found by a friend who I was away with and boy, what a discovery. A small and cosy place but extremely smart at the same time. It's tucked away in a quiet side street between Calle de Goya and Calle...
review_full: This fantastic little place was found by a friend who I was away with and boy, what a discovery. A small and cosy place but extremely smart at the same time.  It's tucked away in a quiet side street between Calle de Goya and Calle de Alcala but not too hard to find. We were staying near Goya station, so only a short stroll away.  I love tapas but have only ever really experienced the 'main stream' offerings. This place takes it to the next level, with contemporary versions of a variety of dishes.  We arrived with hungry bellies and no pre-set idea of what we were going to have. The waiter, who was extremely friendly and professional suggested that we let him select a range of dishes for us, which proved to be a fantastic eclectic mix from fried broccoli to sweetbreads. He also recommended the wines to accompany the food, which were superb and not over priced.  If you try nothing else, have the deep fried broccoli, which was a taste sensation! Something I would never have dreamt of ordering but it turns out to be their signature dish. Worth going their just for that...  Four of us ate until we were comfortably full and drank liberally but the bill only came to 150 euros (without service), which, considering the quality of everything, I thought was fantastic value.  If you are planning to visit Madrid, make the effort to try this place out. If it's not as good as I have said, then it's either changed hands or my taste buds are knackered!  Enjoy..........

review_preview: OK, by now you are tired of Iberian ham, Chorizo, and Patatas Bravas smothered in aioli. Recreo to the rescue. A restaurant that recreates tapas for the modern era and actually serves vegetables, and fruits in their desserts. The restaurant is intimate and cozy with...
review_full: OK, by now you are tired of Iberian ham, Chorizo, and Patatas Bravas smothered in aioli. Recreo to the rescue. A restaurant that recreates tapas for the modern era and actually serves vegetables, and fruits in their desserts. The restaurant is intimate and cozy with a very friendly staff that goes out there way to explain the dishes. If you're an American, like me, whose limited experience with vermouth is in a martini, then start out with a red vermouth aperitif and you'll understand why Spaniards can't get enough of the stuff. It's a limited menu but since each item is exquisitely prepared you will have more than enough to eat. Our server was kind enough to ask us before serving all the dishes we had ordered if we had had enough and our answer was a unanimous yes. My wife and I shared the sardines, mussels, 2 of the the broccoli since they are so good you must have one each, the mushrooms and the Iberian pork sandwich with mustard. Each of the tapas was creatively prepared and delicious. The tomato and bean dish was superb but we were there in the beginning of September when the tomatoes could not have been more perfect. All of this was washed down with Les Crestes, a delicious and very fairly priced wine from Priorat. For dessert we shared the peach yogurt citrus streusel and the chocolate blackberry chantilly, both of which were wonderful. Our only problem now, is where do we we eat dinner tomorrow???

title_review: Restaurants like this make travel worthwhile
review_preview: We were desperately looking for a place for dinner and found this place on trip advisor, made a reservation and caught a cab over from the westin (5 mins). The owner had worked in NY and welcomed us and explained the whole menu. It was...
review_full: We were desperately looking for a place for dinner and found this place on trip advisor, made a reservation and caught a cab over from the westin (5 mins). The owner had worked in NY and welcomed us and explained the whole menu. It was a welcomed different take on traditional spanish food, loved the pulpo with potato foam. mmm. salad with warm goat cheese, fajitas with meat and mango. All good fun, this place is tiny and deserves to succeed. The owner has a lot of talent and if the spanish economy was half decent you would never get into this place. It was a wonderful time and we walked back down to the main road and loved seeing many old buildings (Edificio de Correos) in Madrid being classically highlighted by lights

title_review: We had such a fabulous last night in Madrid at Rosi’s
review_preview: Spanish belowJill and I had enjoyed Madrid so much last year, that we came back for a whole month this year. One reason that we enjoyed it so much was the fabulous Rosi La Loca Taberna restaurant.  We were warmly welcomed again back to...
review_full: Spanish below Jill and I had enjoyed Madrid so much last year, that we came back for a whole month this year. One reason that we enjoyed it so much was the fabulous Rosi La Loca Taberna restaurant.  We were warmly welcomed again back to the restaurant during our first visit back this year. The food and service last year was the best, however this year and they stepped it up even further. The service was just as warm and friendly, but the food presentation was amazing. It is hard to beat. Our first visit this year, was early afternoon, when we had the Menu del Dia. Another wonderful well prepared and beautiful meal. We have a very restricted eating style, and again they were attentive to our requirements. We did not feel that we were inconveniencing our waiter at all. The house wine, which comes with the menu was so good, we ordered it for our final meal in Madrid.  We had the Hawaiian Salad each time we ate at Rosi’s. They offered one of their very best salads for the Menu del Dia.  The had an amazing presentation for lunch, but the supper presentation was to die for. Look at the pictures below we have the tuna and the octopus for supper.  By the way do not go there for supper without a reservation because they are so busy all the time.  The restaurant has such a fun atmosphere at suppertime. The bartender was taking pictures of all his beautiful creations before the waiter takes them to the table. The staff are having so much fun. It makes the meal so much more enjoyable.  When they came out with the tuna it was in a boat with steam coming from dry ice. The picture which I have put in with this review does not do justice for the beauty and excitement created. The tuna that was absolutely the best I’ve ever had.  For the third dish we had the octopus which came with a glass bowl over top with smoke inside. Not only did it look wonderful, it smelled so good with a light wood smoke. See the picture attached. Do yourself a favor and go to Rosi’s. Again do not forget to make a reservation for the evening meal.

review_preview: After four months of living in Madrid, I can easily say that this is my favorite and "go to" restaurant in Madrid. These are not your typical tapas that you can get at every other restaurant in Madrid- these are creative, tasty, and unique tapas....
review_full: After four months of living in Madrid, I can easily say that this is my favorite and "go to" restaurant in Madrid. These are not your typical tapas that you can get at every other restaurant in Madrid- these are creative, tasty, and unique tapas.  I have been here four times and have had most of the items on the menu. You cannot go wrong when ordering here but some of my personal favorites are: goat cheese with basil and honey, tuna tar tar, sobrasada salad, chicken leg with dates and bacon, and the ribs. Once again, you can't go wrong when ordering here- every dish is more delicious than the next. Lastly, the service here has always been incredible. They will tell you how much to order for the amount of people you are with. When the owner is around, he comes up to the table to speak to you and suggest dishes. The staff always gives us free dessert shots at the end of dinner which is also really great. For dessert, order the mojito sorbet; very different than a typical dessert but very delicious.  P.S. make a reservation; its always packed!

The service was very friendly and I will definitely visit this place again, when staying in Madrid.

review_preview: I've just completed a 9 day Spain trip with my family (5 people) and this place was my favorite meal on the trip.We showed up on a Friday night based on tripadvisor reviews without a reservation and were first told that they had no...
review_full: I've just completed a 9 day Spain trip with my family (5 people) and this place was my favorite meal on the trip. We showed up on a Friday night based on tripadvisor reviews without a reservation and were first told that they had no seats for us. Luckily a family at the bar was wrapping up their meal and offered us their seats if we didn't mind sitting at the bar. We took those seats and had no idea what we were in store for. Hugo, whom I assume is the owner, came by and explained each dishes to us in detail which was very impressive since the dishes were not only eclectic but also extremely creative. Hugo said that he has lived in the states before working with Jose Andres which was cool because we had just visited the Bazaar before our trip.  We took a lot of his suggestions and LOVED every dish! I especially enjoyed the calamari, which is nothing like the usual fried calamari in other tapa bars. My family also liked the pork skewers, which had a great cumin flavor. Honestly we liked everything we tried and probably could've returned for another meal to try all the other dishes if we had more time. Hugo was very busy tending to the crowd but always made sure he came by to check up on us throughout the night. He has a great personality and we really enjoyed chatting with him. We really didn't have room for dessert but tried two anyway since everyone else in the restaurant were having them. The mojito dessert was so refreshing and delicious!  I think if you're looking for "traditional" tapas then this is obviously not the place for you, but if you're open minded and would like to try some inventive, tasty, and fun food, then you have to come check this place out!!

review_preview: I've been living in Madrid for just over two months now and this is one of my favourite restaurants!  I've visited this lovely, quirky restaurant three times now and each time has left me feeling full and satisfied. The low lit and lively atmosphere complements...
review_full: I've been living in Madrid for just over two months now and this is one of my favourite restaurants!    I've visited this lovely, quirky restaurant three times now and each time has left me feeling full and satisfied. The low lit and lively atmosphere complements the tasty and typically Spanish dishes, a choice between a variety of tapas and paella.  The menu offers the tapas dishes in two different sizes, 'tapa' and 'super tapa', depending on how hungry you're feeling! My boyfriend and I shared five tapas, all of different sizes, each was soo delicious! The teppanyaki tuna and the classic patatas bravas were a highlight for us. All of the staff are very friendly and chatty, in particular, Jordan was very helpful in recommending whether we had enough food between us or not along with very accommodating. As for the drinks, the sangria is rich with a fruity flavour and refreshing, good to share with a jug! I've also tried the homemade lemonade which I would definitely recommend if you're straying away from the alcoholic drinks. I would recommend to book if you're visiting in a group, especially at the weekends as it can get pretty busy, my boyfriend and I arrived without booking and were allocated a table in under 10 minutes at peak time!  This is a place I take all of my friends to who are visiting from England, and everyone loves it!

review_full: My husband and I ate at Gastromaquia on our last night in Madrid, in July 2014, and we still can't stop wishing that we hadn't discovered it earlier. We still crave the salmorejo and the amazing free range pork skewers (and we aren't even big pork fans - so glad Hugo convinced us to try them!) that we had - when we were in Greece this February, we seriously contemplated flying to Madrid for a day just to eat at Gastromaquia.  This is Michelin star worthy food served in a casual, friendly atmosphere and we cannot recommend it enough! Stellar food - we had the banana chips with guac, patatas bravas, pork skewers (re-ordered 5 times until Hugo had to tell us - no more!), brilliant salmorejo (re-ordered twice), croquettes, and a whole bunch of other stuff that was all superb. We had strawberries with white chocolate cream and the mojito ice cream dessert - both sublime!  Above all, the pork skewers are DIVINE - they are so good that we are planning a trip back just to eat pork skewers at Gastromaquia! An absolute must visit restaurant!

It is not your average tapas experience. The waiters are extremely helpful and even help you pick out your dishes to make sure you don't order too much food but also get to try all the things you want! A table fav was the tuna tartar as well as the papas bravas (we cleaned that plate). The atmosphere is very contemporary, they just moved locations and everything is renovated and up to date. If our stay was longer, we would have definitely been back for another night! Excellent dinner!

review_full: After three weeks in Spain with highs and lows of dining experiences we found this place on our last night. We had a great lunch at Akelarre and a poor paella at La Barraca but this was the best meal in Spain. The smaller and larger plates were great with interesting tastes. The guacamole with banana chips followed by goats cheese, then foie gras with melon were all very good. The mussels with tikka masala was unusual and a bit salty but an unexpected treat and the pork skewers were tasty. Hugo recommended a good red at 16 $€ and this went well with everything. The frozen mojito was a great finish to the meal. Total bill was €62 for two and very good value. Why go to all those tourist traps when you can have food like this?!

review_preview: A hard to find restaurant, tucked away in a side alley, however this is a place you cannot miss. The food is truly gastronomic, with a variety not commonly found in Madrid, definitely a must try if you're Tapas tasting. The owner was extremely helpful...
review_full: A hard to find restaurant, tucked away in a side alley, however this is a place you cannot miss. The food is truly gastronomic, with a variety not commonly found in Madrid, definitely a must try if you're Tapas tasting. The owner was extremely helpful and translated the entire menu and explained each dish so you're quite prepared when you order. The restaurant in itself is quite tiny, so you have to go early if you want a seat, there were quite a few people who were turned away due to lack of availability. Hugely popular with the locals, it was no surprise why when we tried the food there. Tip: get the potato bravas and the spicy clams, and definitely do not leave without having the mojito dessert.

The third had the pulled pork with black beans, rice, and fried plantains. The beef tenderloin was a standout! The sangria tinto was excellent too. They provided English menus and we're friendly and accommodating. The meal was a nice change of pace from traditional Spanish tapas, and I highly recommend it. The bar was lively, even early, and they have vermouth on tap. This is a solid choice with a nice neighborhood feel.

title_review: Michelin star food in a casual environment
review_preview: Phenomenal food and fantastic service! I'm going to say that we got the table next to the door and my heart sank initially but once the friendly waiting staff got going we could not care less.  I would have been happy eating on the pavement...
review_full: Phenomenal food and fantastic service! I'm going to say that we got the table next to the door and my heart sank initially but once the friendly waiting staff got going we could not care less. I would have been happy eating on the pavement with the standard of food we got. We ordered a nice bottle of Albariño and settled in for one of the best meals I have ever had. We consider ourselves pretty spoiled with great food in Edinburgh (Scotland) but the imagination that this restaurant possesses surpasses anything we have in the UK in terms of value. Our second time to Madrid and our third time in this amazing restaurant. The waiting staff guided us through the menu and kept us in order to prevent the typical Brit idiots ordering too much. We had guacamole, foie gras, tuna tartar, deer carpaccio and grilled octopus. The octopus is in a rich creamy sauce so not for everyone but everything else was beautifully fresh and with incredible taste and presentation. A feast for two! We are booked for tomorrow night and cannot wait to try some of the other delicacies on the menu like the goats cheese starter and pigs ear. The waiting staff were great, please be patient initially, it is all well worth the wait. Very reasonable prices for the standard of food and also very reasonably priced and quality wine list.  What can I say, a fancy restaurant with pressed white table cloths this is most definitely not, but it is probably the most charming, atmospheric and best £ for £/€/$ restaurant we have ever been to. Worth the flight from the UK alone!

The mojitos were perfectly prepared and presented, the arepas were delicious, and the beef fajitas were incredible and very filling. Most importantly, the manager was very engaging and welcoming. We enjoyed talking with him about the founding of the restaurant, and the staff's Venezuelan background. A must visit in Madrid!
